If the plaintiff claims costs and disbursements, the plaintiff must file a memorandum setting out the amount claimed and how that amount is calculated, together with any submissions in support of the claim.
A Judge or a Registrar may authorise the sealing of a judgment under subclause (1) if satisfied that the relief claimed by the plaintiff falls within this rule.
A Registrar has the jurisdiction and powers of the court under these rules to fix costs and disbursements under subclause (1)﻿(b).
For the purposes of this rule and rule 15.9, liquidated demand means a sum that—
has been quantified in, or can be precisely calculated on the basis of, a contract relied on by the plaintiff; or
is quantified in, or can be precisely calculated on the basis of, or by reference to, an enactment relied on by the plaintiff; or
has been determined by agreement, mediation, arbitration, or previous litigation between the same parties; or
is a reasonable price for goods supplied or services rendered (when no contract quantifies the price).

history.history-note: Rule 15.7(5)﻿(ab): inserted, on 1 July 2015, by rule 8 of the District Courts Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/103).

para.text: If the relief claimed by the plaintiff is the recovery of land or chattels and the defendant does not file a statement of defence within the number of working days required by the notice of proceeding, the plaintiff may seal judgment that the person whose title is asserted in the statement of claim recover possession of the land or the chattels together with costs and disbursements as fixed by the Registrar.
A Registrar has the jurisdiction and powers of the court under these rules to fix costs and disbursements under subclause (1).

This rule applies if, or to the extent that, the defendant does not file a statement of defence within the number of working days required by the notice of proceeding, and the plaintiff seeks judgment by default for other than a liquidated demand.
The proceeding must be listed for formal proof and no notice is required to be given to the defendant.

After a proceeding is listed for a formal proof hearing, no statement of defence may be filed without the leave of a Judge granted on the ground that there will or may be a miscarriage of justice if judgment by default is entered, and on such terms as to time or otherwise as the Judge thinks just.

The plaintiff must, before or at the formal proof hearing, file affidavit evidence establishing, to a Judge's satisfaction, each cause of action relied on and, if damages are sought, providing sufficient information to enable the Judge to calculate and fix the damages.

If the Judge before or at the formal proof hearing considers that any deponent of an affidavit filed under subclause (4) should attend to give additional evidence, the Judge may direct accordingly and adjourn the hearing for that purpose.

prov.heading: Judgment may be set aside or varied

para.text: Any judgment obtained by default under rule 15.7, 15.8, or 15.9 may be set aside or varied by the court on such terms as it thinks just, if it appears to the court that there has been, or may have been, a miscarriage of justice.

When a document has been served on a party outside New Zealand under rule 6.23 and that party has not appeared, judgment by default against that party must not be sealed without the leave of the court.
Leave must not be granted unless the court is satisfied that—
the party applying for leave was entitled to effect service without leave under rule 6.23; and

there is no reason to believe that the service was effected, or may have been effected, contrary to the law of the country concerned relating to the method of serving documents in domestic actions on persons in that country; and
the service was effected in sufficient time to enable that party to appear.

If a party admits facts (in the party’s pleadings or otherwise), any other party to the proceeding may apply to the court for any judgment or order upon those admissions the other party may be entitled to, without waiting for the determination of any other question between the parties, and the court may give any judgment or order on the application as it thinks just.
This rule is not affected by rules 15.13 and 15.14.

At any time after a party has been served with a notice of proceeding, that party may file and serve (separately from the party’s pleadings) an admission of all, some, or part of the alleged causes of action on all other parties to the proceeding.
An admission can be withdrawn only with the leave of the court.

When an admission is filed and served under subclause (1), a party on whom the admission is served may seal judgment on the cause of action admitted, without prejudice to that party’s right (if any) to proceed on any other cause of action.
An admission under subclause (1) relating to any cause of action in which a sum of money is claimed must state the exact amount admitted.
Any judgment entered on an admission filed and served under subclause (1) may, upon application, be set aside by the court if—
the plaintiff, being under a duty or obligation to the defendant not to enter judgment on the admission, acted contrary to that duty or obligation in entering judgment; or
the plaintiff, in entering judgment, acted fraudulently, unconscionably, or in wilful or reckless disregard of the defendant’s rights.
Upon an application under subclause (5), the court may direct that a proceeding be brought to determine whether judgment was wrongfully entered.
This rule does not affect rule 8.48.

When a party’s original or amended statement of defence alleges any ground of defence that goes to the whole of any cause of action alleged by the other party, the other party may file and serve an admission of that ground of defence.

If the admitted ground of defence arose after the filing of the pleading containing the cause of action to which it refers, the party filing and serving the admission is entitled to an order for that party’s costs in respect of the cause of action to which the admission applies, up to the time of filing the statement of defence, unless the court otherwise orders.
Subject to subclause (2), a party on whom an admission has been served under subclause (1) may at any time afterwards seal judgment upon the cause of action to which the admission relates.
This rule does not affect rule 8.48.
For the purposes of rules 15.16 to 15.22, a reference to discontinuing a proceeding means discontinuing a proceeding against 1 or more defendants.
At any time before the giving of judgment or a verdict, a plaintiff may discontinue a proceeding by—
filing a notice of discontinuance and serving a copy of the notice on every other party to the proceeding; or
orally advising the court at the hearing that the proceeding is discontinued.
A notice of discontinuance under subclause (1)﻿(a) must be in form 36.
This rule is subject to rule 15.17.

prov.heading: Restrictions on right to discontinue proceeding

para.text: A plaintiff may discontinue a proceeding only with the leave of the court if a party to the proceeding has given an undertaking to the court.

A plaintiff to whom an interim payment has been made, whether voluntarily or under an order made under rule 7.62 or 7.63, may discontinue the proceeding only with the written consent of the party by whom the payment was made or with the leave of the court.

A plaintiff may discontinue a proceeding in which there is more than 1 plaintiff only with the consent of every other plaintiff or with the leave of the court. If the plaintiff files a notice of discontinuance under rule 15.16(1)﻿(a), the consent of every other plaintiff must be in writing.

If there is more than 1 defendant in a proceeding, a plaintiff may discontinue a proceeding against a particular defendant only with the consent of every other defendant or with the leave of the court. If the plaintiff files a notice of discontinuance under rule 15.16(1)﻿(a), the consent of every other defendant must be in writing.
A proceeding ends against a defendant or defendants on—
the filing and service of a notice of discontinuance under rule 15.16(1)﻿(a); or
the giving of oral advice of the discontinuance at the hearing under rule 15.16(1)﻿(b); or
the making of an order under rule 15.17.
The discontinuance of a proceeding does not affect the determination of costs.
Rule 15.19 overrides this rule.

The court may, on the application of a defendant against whom a proceeding is discontinued, make an order setting the discontinuance aside if it is satisfied that the discontinuance is an abuse of the process of the court.
An application under subclause (1) must be made within 25 working days after discontinuance under rule 15.16.

Unless the defendant otherwise agrees or the court otherwise orders, a plaintiff who discontinues a proceeding against a defendant must pay costs to the defendant of and incidental to the proceeding up to and including the discontinuance.

A plaintiff who discontinues a proceeding (proceeding A) against a defendant may not commence another proceeding (proceeding B) against the defendant if proceeding B arises out of facts that are the same or substantially the same as those relating to proceeding A, unless the plaintiff has paid any costs ordered to be paid to the defendant under rule 15.20 relating to proceeding A.

If a plaintiff discontinues a proceeding in which a defendant has issued a third party notice under rules 4.4 to 4.17 or has filed a notice under rules 4.18 to 4.21, the discontinuance does not affect the continuation of the proceeding in relation to the third party notice or the notice filed under rules 4.18 to 4.21.
In this Part,—
account-taker has the meaning set out in rule 16.6
accounting party means—
the party required by an order for the taking of an account to account to the other party; and
in a case coming within rule 16.5, each party.
The court may, on the application of any party, before, at, or after the trial of a proceeding, order an account or an inquiry, whether or not it has been claimed in that party’s pleading.
At the time of ordering an account or an inquiry, or at another time, the court may—
give directions or further directions about the account or inquiry:
order additional accounts or inquiries:
direct that the relevant books of account are prima facie evidence of the truth of the matters contained in them.
An order or direction under subclause (1) overrides rules 16.6 to 16.20.
If a party’s pleading claims an account or makes a claim that involves taking an account, the court may, on application by that party at any stage of the proceeding, order—
an account; and
that any amount certified on the account as due to any party be paid to that party.
The court must not make an order under subclause (1)—
if there is some preliminary question to be determined; or
against a defendant who has not filed a statement of defence or an appearance, until the time for filing a statement of defence has expired.
The court may order that each party account to the other if it considers that each is accountable to the other because of—
the relationship between the parties; or
their course of dealing; or
any other reason.
At the time of making an order under subclause (1), or at any time afterwards, the court may direct—
that the result of the account be certified as the net balance found to be due to 1 party; or
that the certificate show the amounts found to be due to each party.
An order under this rule overrides rules 16.6 to 16.20.
The court may order accounts to be taken before an account-taker, who may be—
the Registrar; or
an accountant; or
the Registrar and an accountant.
Unless otherwise ordered, an accountant who takes an account must be a qualified statutory accountant (within the meaning of section 5(1) of the Financial Reporting Act 2013).

history.history-note: Rule 16.6(2): amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 9 of the District Courts Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/103).

para.text: The court may direct that any evidence relevant to the account be given to the account-taker, with any incidental order the court thinks just.
The court must fix the remuneration of an accountant who is an account-taker. The order doing so may cover incidental matters including (for example) 1 or both of the following:
that the remuneration be paid by 1 or more of the parties in any proportions:
that 1 or more of the parties give security for the remuneration of the accountant, on terms the court thinks just.
Subclause (1) does not limit the court’s power to make an order providing for the payment of the remuneration as part of the costs of the proceeding.
The items on each side of an account must be numbered consecutively.
An accounting party must verify the account by affidavit, and must attach the account as an exhibit.
Within 10 working days after the order to account has been served on an accounting party, that party must—
file the account and verifying affidavit; and
serve a copy of the account and verifying affidavit on each other party.

prov.heading: Notice of receipt that is not admitted

para.text: A party who alleges an accounting party has received an amount that is not admitted in the accounting party’s account must, within 10 working days after being served with the account, notify the accounting party of the allegation, stating (as far as possible) the amount and brief particulars.

A party who alleges that any item in an accounting party’s account is erroneous in amount or otherwise must, within 10 working days after being served with the account, notify the accounting party of the allegation, stating the grounds for alleging the error.
Except to the extent shown in a notice given under rule 16.11 or 16.12, all items in the account must be treated as correct.

prov.heading: Appointment and notice for taking accounts

para.text: As soon as possible after the accounting party has filed the account, the account-taker must—
appoint a time (no less than 15 working days after the filing date) and a place for taking the account (the account hearing); and
give notice of that time and place to the parties no less than 5 working days before the account hearing date.
The parties or their solicitors or counsel must attend the account hearing.
If the account-taker is satisfied that notice of the time and place has been given and received, the account-taker may proceed with the account hearing, even if any party is absent.
The account-taker may adjourn the time and place of the account hearing as necessary or expedient.
The account-taker may decide all disputed items of account summarily.
Despite subclause (1),—
any item may be referred for the decision of the court by—
any party; or
the account-taker; and
all items of account in respect of which the Registrar and an accountant disagree must be referred for the decision of the court.

If an item has been referred to the court under rule 16.17(2), the court may, on the application of a party who has given a notice under rule 16.11 or 16.12, order that the accounting party appear before the court to be examined orally about the disputed item of account.

The accounting party must, when required by written notice, produce all invoices, statements of account, receipts, and any other documents in that party’s possession or power relating to any disputed item of account specified in the notice at—
the taking of the account; or
the examination of the accounting party under rule 16.18.

prov.heading: Interest on debts of deceased person

para.text: A court ordering an account of the debts of a deceased person may order—
which debts carry interest; and
the date from which the debts carry interest (for example, from the date of the order); and
the rate of interest for each debt, which may be—
the rate prescribed by the instrument or instruments creating the debt or debts; or
if no rate is so prescribed, the rate prescribed by or under section 62B of the Act.
Any amount which has been paid or credited must be brought into account.

If there is no material before the account-taker which enables an amount to be ascertained with certainty, the account-taker may estimate the amount which in all the circumstances should reasonably be included.
The court may direct the Registrar or any other person to make inquiries (in any manner and within any time period) about—
next of kin:
creditors:
other claimants:
any other similar matters.

prov.heading: Powers of persons taking accounts or making inquiries

para.text: The account-taker or the person whom the court directs to make an inquiry may—
issue advertisements; and
summon parties and witnesses; and
administer oaths; and
receive affidavits and acknowledgments; and
examine parties and witnesses either by interrogatories or by hearing them in person.

prov.heading: Duty of persons summoned to attend

para.text: A person must attend an account-taker or a person taking an inquiry—
in accordance with a summons; and
at any other time required without a further summons.
A person who fails to attend after being summoned is liable to the same extent as if he or she had disobeyed a court order.
The court must fix and advertise the time within which persons must prove their claims (for example, as creditors or next of kin).
The time must not be less than 25 working days after the date on which the advertisement is first published.

prov.heading: Statement of claim to be filed

para.text: A person claiming as a creditor, next of kin, or otherwise must file a statement of claim verified by an affidavit.
A person who does not prove a claim within the advertised time is excluded from the benefit of the judgment or order directing accounts or inquiries.
Subclause (1) is subject to sections 75, 76, and 76A of the Trustee Act 1956.
The result of any account or inquiry must be stated in a short certificate to the court, unless the court orders the result to be recorded in a formal report.

prov.heading: Party may ask for court’s decision

para.text: At any time before the end of 10 working days after a certificate or report has been completed, but before it has been signed by a Judge, any party may ask for the court’s decision on any particular point or on the result.

prov.heading: Certificate or report when approved to be signed by Judge

para.text: A Judge must sign a certificate or report stated or recorded under rule 16.28 when he or she has approved it.
The Registrar must file the signed certificate or report in the court.

prov.heading: Effect of certificate or report when filed

para.text: A certificate or report that has been filed in the court is binding on all parties to the proceeding, unless discharged or varied by the court after an application made within 25 working days.
Subclause (1) does not prevent the court from reopening a certificate or report at any time on the grounds of fraud, surprise, or mistake.

prov.heading: Distribution before all persons entitled are ascertained

para.text: The court may order the immediate payment of a party’s share to that party—
even if the other persons who are entitled to shares are not ascertained and there is likely to be difficulty or delay in ascertaining those others; and
without reserving any part of the share to meet the subsequent costs of ascertaining those others.

prov.heading: Payment of share carried over to separate trust account

para.text: If the rights or circumstances of the parties at the time of judgment do not enable the court to order absolutely that payment be made to the persons entitled, the court may order any party’s share that has not become absolute to be carried over on trust to a separate account.

A party that becomes entitled to a share held in trust under subclause (1) may apply for payment of the share on notice to the other persons interested in the matter, and the court may order payment to that party.

prov.heading: Report under section 62 or 62A of Act

para.text: A report under section 62 or 62A of the Act—
must be in writing; and
must be filed in the registry of the court; and
is open to inspection by the parties.
The Registrar must, on the filing of the report, give notice of the report to all parties.
When the report has been filed,—
if the further consideration of the proceeding has been adjourned to a particular day, any party may—
apply on that day to a Judge to adopt the report; or

give not less than 3 working days' notice of the party's intention to make an application on that day to vary the report or to remit the report or any part of the report for further inquiry or report:
if the further consideration has not been adjourned to a particular day, any party may, on not less than 3 working days' notice, apply to a Judge to—
adopt or vary the report; or
remit the report or any part of the report for further inquiry and report.

prov.heading: Abandonment of excess if more than $200,000 found due on taking of accounts

para.text: This rule applies if, on taking an account, it appears that a plaintiff is entitled to a larger amount than $200,000, and the plaintiff has not by the plaintiff's notice of claim or statement of claim abandoned the excess over $200,000.

The plaintiff may, if the defendant does not agree to extend the jurisdiction of the court under section 37 of the Act, by leave of the court abandon the excess over $200,000, and judgment may be entered accordingly.
An agreement not to appeal must be in form 37 and must be filed in the court before the trial.
An application for leave to appeal must be made on notice in form 38.
This Part applies to appeals to the District Court in its civil jurisdiction.
In this Part,—
administrative office means the registry or office or other place at which the decision-maker gave the decision appealed against
administrative officer means the Registrar, secretary, or other officer responsible for the administration of the administrative office
decision includes a finding, an order, or a judgment made by a decision-maker
decision-maker means a tribunal, person, or body of persons—
that exercises a power of decision from which there is, or may be, a right of appeal to the court; and
against the decision of which an appeal is brought or sought to be brought
registry means the registry of the court—
at which an appeal is required to be filed under rule 18.8(1); or
to which documents relating to an appeal are transferred under rule 18.8(3).

prov.heading: Judge may call conference and give directions

para.text: For the purpose of ensuring that any appeal is determined in a convenient and expeditious manner, and that all matters in dispute are effectively and completely determined, a Judge may hold a conference of parties or counsel presided over by the Judge—
at any time, and on any terms the Judge thinks fit:
on the application of any party or without application.
A Judge presiding at a conference may—
settle the issues to be determined:
direct which persons are to be named as the respondents, or direct that the name of any party be added or struck out:
fix a time for the filing of affidavits or other documents:
fix a time and place for the hearing of the appeal:
make an order in accordance with rule 18.15:
give directions as to the manner in which evidence is to be brought before the court at the hearing of the appeal:
give any other directions necessary for the proper determination of the appeal.
At any time before the hearing of an appeal has started, a Judge may, for the purposes of subclause (1), exercise any of the powers specified in subclause (2) without holding a conference.

prov.heading: Time for appeal if there is right of appeal

para.text: This rule applies if a party has a right of appeal to the court.
An appeal must be brought—
within the specified period if the enactment that confers the right of appeal specifies a period within which the appeal must be brought; or
in every other case, within 20 working days after the decision appealed against is given.
By special leave, the court may extend the time prescribed for appealing if the enactment that confers the right of appeal—
permits the extension; or
does not limit the time prescribed for bringing the appeal.
An application for an extension—
must be made by an interlocutory application on notice to every other party affected by the appeal; and
may be made before or after the expiry of the time for appealing.
For the purposes of rule 18.4, a period begins when the decision to which it relates is given, whether or not—
reasons for the decision are given then or later; or
formal steps, such as entering or sealing the decision, are necessary or are taken after the decision is given.
An appeal is brought when the appellant—
files a notice of appeal in the court; and
files a copy of the notice of appeal in the administrative office; and
serves a copy of the notice of appeal on every other party directly affected by the appeal.
Service at the address for service stated in the proceedings to which the appeal relates is sufficient service for the purposes of subclause (1).
Despite rule 18.6(1)﻿(c), the court may dispense with service on a party of a notice of appeal on any terms the court thinks just.
Subject to any contrary enactment, a notice of appeal must be filed in—
the registry of the court nearest to the place where the hearing took place of the matter under appeal; or
if no hearing took place, in the registry of the court nearest to the place where the decision appealed against was given; or
any other registry of the court in which the parties agree that the notice of appeal may be filed.

If subclause (1)﻿(c) applies, the parties must endorse on, or file with, the notice of appeal a memorandum recording their agreement to the filing of the notice of appeal in the registry of the court in which it is filed.
The court may on application or on its own initiative in the circumstances set out in subclause (4) direct as follows:
the notice of appeal must be filed in another registry of the court; or
the documents relating to the appeal must be transferred to another registry of the court.
The circumstances are that it appears to the court that—
a notice of appeal has been filed in the wrong registry of the court; or
another registry of the court would be more appropriate.
Filing a notice of appeal in the wrong registry of the court does not invalidate an appeal.
The notice of appeal must, unless the court directs otherwise,—
bear a heading in form 2 that—
refers to the enactment under which the appeal is brought; and
refers to the matter as being in the matter of an appeal from a decision of a tribunal or person; and
specify the decision or the part of the decision appealed from; and
specify any error of law alleged by the appellant; and
specify any question of law to be resolved; and
specify the grounds of the appeal in sufficient detail to give full advice of the issues involved to the court, the other parties, and the decision-maker; and
specify the relief sought.
The grounds of the appeal may be amended by leave of the court.
The notice of appeal must not name the decision-maker as a respondent.

prov.heading: Stay of decision subject to appeal

para.text: An appeal against a decision by a decision-maker does not operate as a stay—
of the decision appealed against; or
of enforcement of any order appealed against.
Despite subclause (1), the court may, on application, do any 1 or more of the following pending determination of an appeal against a decision by a decision-maker:
order a stay of proceedings in relation to the decision appealed against:
order a stay of enforcement of any order appealed against:
grant any interim relief.
An order made or relief granted under subclause (2) may—
relate to enforcement of the whole of an order or other decision or to a particular form of enforcement:
be subject to any conditions for the giving of security the decision-maker or the court thinks just.
A respondent wishing to contend at the hearing of an appeal that the decision appealed against should be varied must—
file a notice of cross-appeal in the registry of the court; and
file a copy of the notice in the administrative office; and
serve a copy of the notice on every other party directly affected by the cross-appeal.
A notice of cross-appeal must be filed no later than 2 working days before the case management conference relating to the appeal, except with the leave of the court.
A notice of cross-appeal must specify—
the decision or part of the decision to which the cross-appeal relates; and
the grounds of the cross-appeal in sufficient detail to fully inform the court, the other parties to the appeal, and the decision-maker of the issues in the cross-appeal; and
the relief sought.
The court may, despite a respondent's failure to file and serve a notice of cross-appeal,—
allow the respondent to contend at the hearing that the decision appealed against should be varied; or
adjourn the hearing to allow the respondent time to file and serve a notice; or
make any other order the court thinks just, including an order for the payment of costs.
A respondent may amend a notice of cross-appeal at any time with the leave of the court.

prov.heading: Dismissal or stay or abandonment of appeal or cross-appeal

para.text: The court may, on application, dismiss or stay an appeal or a cross-appeal if the court is satisfied that the appellant or the respondent has failed to proceed with it, or has failed to comply with a direction relating to the conduct of the appeal.

The appeal is taken to have been dismissed, subject to the respondent's right to apply for an order as to costs, if the appellant signs, files, and serves on every other party a statement to the effect that the appellant abandons the appeal.

The cross-appeal is taken to have been dismissed, subject to the appellant's right to apply for an order as to costs, if the respondent signs, files, and serves on every other party a statement to the effect that the respondent abandons the cross-appeal.
This rule applies to an appeal other than an appeal for which the appellant has been granted legal aid under the Legal Services Act 2011.
The Judge must fix security for costs at the case management conference relating to the appeal, unless the Judge considers that in the interests of justice no security is required.
The amount of security must be fixed in accordance with the following formula, unless the Judge otherwise directs:
where—
is the daily recovery rate for the proceeding as classified by the Judge under rule 14.4; and
is the number of half days estimated by the Judge as the time required for the hearing.
Security must be paid to the Registrar at the registry of the court no later than 10 working days after the case management conference, unless the Judge otherwise directs.
If the security is not paid within the time specified under subclause (4), the respondent may apply for an order dismissing the appeal.
The Judge must defer the fixing of security until the application for legal aid has been determined if—
an appellant has applied for legal aid under the Legal Services Act 2011; and
at the time of the case management conference, the application has not been determined.

prov.heading: Documents to be lodged with Registrar

para.text: The administrative officer of the decision-maker must, as soon as possible after being served with the notice of appeal, send to the Registrar at the court at the appropriate place—
2 copies of any papers that are lodged with the decision-maker and that relate to the decision appealed from; and
any exhibits in the custody of the decision-maker; and
2 copies of the whole of the decision appealed from.
Subclause (1) applies unless the court otherwise directs.

The administrative officer must also send to the Registrar 2 copies of any transcribed notes of any evidence given at any hearing before the decision-maker that were made for the purposes of, or under the direction of, the decision-maker.
No further verification is required of the contents of any transcript provided under subclause (3) if the administrative officer has certified it as correct.

If an enactment provides for the appointment of a person other than a Judge to sit with the court or as a member of the court to hear any specified appeal, the number of copies of documents required by subclauses (1)﻿(a) and (c) and (3) must be increased to a number sufficient to provide a copy each for the court records, the Judge, and every other person required to hear the appeal.
Subclause (3) does not apply to any notes made personally by the decision-maker or (if the decision-maker is a tribunal) a member of the tribunal.
The court may order, on application, that—
a transcript be made of all or part of the evidence given at the hearing before the decision-maker; and
the transcript be sent to the Registrar at the registry of the court.
An application under subclause (1) must be filed no later than the first of the following dates:
the date that is 20 working days after the date on which notice of appeal is filed in the court:
the working day before the date of the case management conference.
The court must give notice to the decision-maker before making an order for a transcript.

A decision-maker who wishes to appear and be heard before an order for a transcript is made must file, within 14 days after the date of being served notice under subclause (3), a notice of intention to appear and be heard.
A notice filed under subclause (4) entitles the decision-maker and every party to the appeal to be heard before an order for a transcript is made.
The court may, if it thinks fit, require a report to be made and lodged under rule 18.16 instead of requiring a transcript.
The decision-maker may apply at any time to the court for an order that the parties to the appeal pay for the cost of making the transcript.
The court may make an order for a transcript—
on any conditions that it thinks fit:
even if the appeal is abandoned, or dismissed for want of prosecution.
The following provisions apply once the order is made:
a sealed copy of the order must be served immediately on the decision-maker:
the decision-maker must certify the correctness of the transcript and send a copy of the transcript to the Registrar at the appropriate court:
no further verification is required of the contents of the certified transcript.
In subclause (9), decision-maker includes an administrative officer of the decision-maker.
The decision-maker must, if the court directs, provide to the Registrar at the registry of the court a report setting out—
any considerations, other than findings of fact, not set out in the decision but to which the decision-maker had regard in making the decision appealed against:
any information about the effect that the decision might have on the general administration of the enactment under which the decision was made:
any other matters relevant to the decision or to the general administration of the enactment under which the decision was made that should be drawn to the attention of the court.
The Registrar must provide a copy of the report to every party to the appeal.
Every party to the appeal is entitled to be heard, and tender evidence, on any matter referred to in the report.
Without leave, a party to an appeal may adduce further evidence on a question of fact if the evidence is necessary to determine an interlocutory application that relates to the appeal.
In all other cases, a party to an appeal may adduce further evidence only with the leave of the court.

The court may grant leave only if there are special reasons for hearing the evidence. An example of a special reason is that the evidence relates to matters that have arisen after the date of the decision appealed against and that are or may be relevant to the determination of the appeal.
Further evidence under this rule must be given by affidavit, unless the court otherwise directs.

prov.heading: Decision-maker entitled to be heard on appeal

para.text: The decision-maker is entitled, after obtaining the leave of the court, to be represented and heard at the hearing of an appeal on all matters arising in it, unless the decision-maker is the Disputes Tribunal or a Tenancy Tribunal or a Registrar.
Appeals are by way of rehearing.

prov.heading: Powers of court in relation to evidence heard on appeal

para.text: The court has full discretionary power to rehear all or any part of evidence taken before the decision-maker.

The court must rehear the evidence of any witness if the court has reason to believe that any note of the evidence of that witness made by direction of the decision-maker is or may be incomplete in any material particular.
The court has full discretionary power to hear and receive further evidence on questions of fact, either by oral evidence or by affidavit.

The court must also have regard to any report lodged by the decision-maker under rule 18.16, including any matters referred to in the report and any evidence tendered on the report, whether or not those matters would otherwise be admissible in evidence.

The court may, in exercising its powers under this rule and rules 18.21 to 18.24, receive as evidence any statement, document, information, or matter that the decision-maker would have been entitled to receive at the hearing at first instance.
In any appeal, the court has all the powers and discretions of the decision-maker—
to hold the hearing or any part of it in private; and
to make orders prohibiting the publication of any report or description of the proceedings or any part of them.
In any appeal, the Solicitor-General must, at the request of the court, appoint counsel to appear and be heard as counsel assisting the court.

prov.heading: Appeals from decision arising from contested application

para.text: At the hearing of any appeal from a decision made arising from a contested application, the decision-maker is entitled, after obtaining the leave of the court, to be represented and heard on—
any issue relating to the procedure followed in the course of reaching the decision appealed from; or
any issue relating to the decision-maker or, if the decision-maker is a tribunal, members of the tribunal; or
any matter that the decision-maker has referred to in a report made under rule 18.16.
The decision-maker is not entitled to be represented and heard on any other issue or matter arising in the appeal.
After hearing an appeal, the court may do any 1 or more of the following:
make any decision it thinks should have been made:
direct the decision-maker—
to rehear the proceedings concerned; or
to consider or determine (whether for the first time or again) any matters the court directs; or
to enter judgment for any party to the proceedings the court directs:
make any order the court thinks just, including any order as to costs.
The court must state its reasons for giving a direction under subclause (1)﻿(b).
The court may give the decision-maker any direction it thinks fit relating to—
rehearing any proceedings directed to be reheard; or
considering or determining any matter directed to be considered or determined.
The court may act under subclause (1) in respect of a whole decision, even if the appeal is against only part of it.
Even if an interlocutory or similar decision in the proceedings has not been appealed against, the court—
may act under subclause (1); and
may set the interlocutory or similar decision aside; and
if it sets the interlocutory or similar decision aside, may make in its place any interlocutory or similar decision the decision-maker could have made.
The powers given by this rule may be exercised in favour of a respondent or party to the proceedings concerned, even if the respondent or party did not appeal against the decision concerned.
The court may dismiss the appeal—
if the appellant does not appear at the time appointed for hearing the appeal; or
on the application of any other party or the decision-maker, if the appellant does not prosecute the appeal with due diligence.

prov.heading: Repayment of judgment sum and interest

para.text: Subclause (2) applies when—
a party to proceedings before a decision-maker (party A) has, in accordance with a judgment or order of the decision-maker, paid an amount to another party to the proceedings (party B); and
on appeal to the court, the effect of the court's determination is that some or all of the amount did not need to be paid.
When this subclause applies, the court—
may order party B to repay to party A some or all of the amount paid by party A; and
may also order party B to pay to party A interest at a rate no greater than the rate prescribed by or under section 62B of the District Courts Act 1947 on the sum ordered to be repaid.

prov.heading: Registrar to notify decision of court

para.text: On the determination of any appeal, the Registrar must send to the appropriate officer of the decision-maker or (if the decision-maker is an individual) to the decision-maker—
a memorandum of the court's decision; and
any application, papers, and exhibits forwarded to the Registrar under rule 18.14 or 18.15.

part.heading: Enforcement

para.text: A person liable to pay money under a judgment or order may at any time pay money into court to reduce the amount payable by that person.
Personal property that is to be sold under a direction in a judgment or order may be sold by public auction or private contract as the Judge directs.
The Registrar must, if the Judge directs, supervise any sale, detention, or preservation of personal property that has been directed to be sold by public auction or to be detained or preserved.
The Registrar must, unless the Judge directs otherwise, ensure that personal property that has been directed to be sold by private contract is sold in accordance with the Judge's directions.
This rule does not apply to enforcement issued under section 79(1)﻿(a) of the Act.

If any difficulty arises in relation to the enforcement of a judgment or order for relief other than the payment of money, the Judge or Registrar may, on the application of an interested party, make an order for the attendance and examination of any party or otherwise as the Judge or Registrar thinks fit in the interests of justice.

prov.heading: Application by judgment creditor of partner

para.text: An application by a separate judgment creditor of a partner for any order under section 26 of the Partnership Act 1908 must be made to the court on notice.
The notice and any order made on the application must be served on—
the judgment debtor; and
the partners of the judgment debtor who are in New Zealand.

prov.heading: Application by partner of judgment debtor

para.text: An application by a partner of a judgment debtor under section 26 of the Partnership Act 1908 must be made to the court on notice.
The notice must be served on—
the judgment creditor; and
the judgment debtor; and
the partners of the judgment debtor who do not agree with the application and are in New Zealand.
This rule applies if any change has taken place after judgment by death, assignment, or otherwise—
in the parties entitled to a judgment or order; or
in the parties liable under a judgment or order.
When this rule applies, the party claiming to be entitled to enforce the judgment or order may apply without notice to the court or a Registrar for leave to issue the necessary process.
The court or a Registrar may,—
if satisfied that the party applying is entitled to issue the process, make an order to that effect:
if not so satisfied, order that any issue or question necessary to determine the rights of the parties be tried and determined in a manner that the court or Registrar thinks fit.

Despite anything in rule 5.1, the hearing of any issue or question referred to in subclause (3)﻿(b) must be started in the court in which the order was made, unless the court or a Registrar otherwise orders.
Any order made under subclause (3) must be in form 39 and be served on the persons affected.
No process may issue from an order made under subclause (3) until 5 working days have expired after the date of service, unless the court or a Registrar gives leave.
A party claiming to be entitled, by reason of the same change, to enforce more than 1 judgment or order may—
make 1 application in which all the judgments or orders are specified in a schedule; and
set out, in the notice of any order made on the application, only that part of the order affecting the person to be served notice.

prov.heading: Change of name, etc, of party after judgment

para.text: If the name, address, or occupation of any party to a judgment or order differs from that specified in any application for any process for the enforcement of a judgment or order,—
the applicant must satisfy the Registrar that the amended name, address, or occupation applies to that party; and
both names, addresses, or occupations, as the case may require, must be specified in the process applied for.

prov.heading: Application to Registrar for suspension of judgment, etc

para.text: A person who wishes to apply to the court to suspend or stay any judgment, order, enforcement, or order of committal may apply to a Registrar in the absence of the Judge.
The Registrar may suspend or stay the judgment, order, enforcement, or order of committal until an application can be made to the Judge.
An order to suspend or stay any judgment, order, enforcement, order of committal, or order for the discharge of a person under the Act must be in form 40.
A warrant must be recalled if—
an order suspending or staying a judgment, order, or enforcement has been made; and
enforcement has been issued.
Even if a warrant is recalled, a Judge may—
order the person named in the warrant to pay the costs of the warrant and any fees or expenses incurred by the bailiff before the recall of the warrant; and
authorise the bailiff to sell part of the goods seized sufficient to pay for the costs, fees, and expenses referred to in paragraph (a), and the expenses of the sale; and
give leave to reissue the warrant.

prov.heading: Discharge of person under section 98 of Act

para.text: This rule applies if an order has been made under section 98 of the Act for the discharge of any person arrested or confined in prison under section 79(2) or (4) of the Act.
The Registrar of the court must send a copy of the order to the prison manager or bailiff who has custody of the person.
The prison manager or bailiff must, on receipt of the copy of the order, promptly discharge the person in custody.
If the terms of a discharge referred to in subclause (1) include liability to rearrest if the terms are not complied with,—
the party entitled to the benefit of the judgment or order may, if the terms are not complied with, apply to the court on notice; and
the court may order the person to be rearrested and imprisoned for that part of the term of imprisonment that remains unserved at the time of that person’s discharge.
If an order is made under subclause (4)﻿(b), an order must be issued and delivered to the bailiff authorising—
the bailiff to rearrest the person; and
the prison manager to receive and detain that person for the remainder of the term of imprisonment or until that person is sooner discharged in due course of law.

prov.heading: Receipt to be attached to warrant

para.text: When money is paid on a warrant under an enforcement process, the bailiff or constable must promptly complete and sign a receipt and hand it to the defendant or the person paying the money.
The bailiff or constable must pay to a Registrar the money that he or she collected under the warrant.
If money is not received, the constable or bailiff must endorse that fact on the warrant.
The bailiff must—
keep and maintain, in an appropriate form, a record of all warrants, writs, and other processes that the bailiff has received for enforcement or service; and
include in the record the date when each process was received; and
include in the record—
the date of enforcement or service of each warrant, writ, or other process; and
either—
a brief description of the outcome of the enforcement or service; or
if the warrant, writ, or other process was not enforced or served during the time it was in force, the reason for its non-enforcement or non-service.

prov.heading: New order for payment of unsatisfied judgment

para.text: If there is an unsatisfied judgment or order,—
a party entitled to enforce it may apply to the court for an order that the amount due and unpaid be paid—
by instalments; or
if already payable by instalments, by the same or smaller instalments; and
the court may make an order on the application accordingly.
If it appears to the court that a person liable under a judgment or order for the payment of a sum of money is unable to pay it in 1 sum, the court may, on application by the person liable,—
order that the unpaid amount be paid by instalments:
vary any order made under paragraph (a).

If it appears to the court that a person liable under any order for payment by instalments is able to pay the sum ordered to be paid in 1 sum or by larger or earlier instalments than those ordered, the court may, on application by the person entitled to enforce the order,—
order that the unpaid amount be paid in 1 sum or by larger or earlier instalments; and
vary any order made under paragraph (a).
All applications under this rule must be made on notice in form 41.
This rule applies to any application for a civil enforcement process to which this Part or Part 6 of the Act applies.
The application must be in a form approved in accordance with the Act (if any) or prescribed by these rules.
If 2 or more judgment debtors are liable under the same judgment or order,—
a separate application may be filed in respect of each debtor concerned; and
a separate application must be filed in respect of each debtor whom the judgment creditor wishes to be subject to the civil enforcement process; and
fees must be paid and costs allowed in respect of each application.

A judgment creditor is not required to state in an application relating to a judgment debtor that is a body corporate the name of a particular officer who is to appear at any hearing relating to the application.
This rule applies if—
a financial assessment hearing or a hearing under section 84D of the Act is to be held; and
the judgment debtor resides or carries on business 35 km or more from the registry of the court—
from which the request to the judgment debtor under section 84C of the Act is made by the court or a Registrar; or
in which an application relating to the judgment debtor is filed under section 84E of the Act.

The court or a Registrar may order that the hearing be held before the court at the place nearest, or at any place (whether or not a court) near, to where the judgment debtor resides or carries on business.
A Registrar must appoint a date and time for the hearing and arrange for service of the notice of hearing in accordance with section 108A of the Act.

prov.heading: Non-appearance of judgment creditor or witness at assessment

para.text: Whether or not a judgment creditor appears at the financial assessment hearing under section 84EB of the Act, the court or a Registrar may, unless subclause (2) applies, make any order or give any direction under section 84EC of the Act.

The court or a Registrar may adjourn the assessment if it appears to the court or Registrar that the assessment cannot fairly proceed owing to the absence of either the judgment creditor or a witness.
An adjournment under subclause (2)—
is subject to the payment of costs and travel expenses as the court or Registrar thinks fit in the interests of justice; and
must always be to a fixed date.
The court or a Registrar must keep a record of—
the date and time of each hearing held under section 84D or 84EB of the Act; and
the terms of anything done by the court or a Registrar under section 84EC of the Act.
A copy of the record kept under subclause (1) must be provided to every party to the proceeding.
A warrant to arrest a judgment debtor (or relevant officer) issued under section 84EA of the Act must be in form 42.
A person applying under section 84N of the Act for a review of an order or direction made by a Registrar must—
make the notice of application in form 43; and
specify in the application the grounds on which it is made in sufficient detail to fully advise the court and other parties of the issues involved.
An application under section 84O(3) of the Act for an order that the judgment debtor do community work must—
be in form 44; and
specify the grounds on which it is made in sufficient detail to fully advise the court and other parties of the issues involved; and
be authenticated by the judgment creditor or the judgment creditor’s solicitor or an agent authorised in writing by the judgment creditor to authenticate the application.
An application that is authenticated by an agent must be filed with an authority in form 45.
The following documents must be served personally on the judgment debtor not less than 3 working days before the date of the hearing:
a copy of the application; and
a summons in form 46 requiring the attendance of the judgment debtor at the hearing of the application.
An order for community work issued under section 84O(3) of the Act must be in form 47.
A warrant to arrest a judgment debtor issued under section 84OB(1) of the Act must be in form 48.

prov.heading: Hearing of contempt of enforcement proceedings if judgment debtor at distance

para.text: If the judgment debtor resides or carries on business 35 km or more from the registry of the court in which the application for an order that the judgment debtor do community work is made, the court or a Registrar may direct that the hearing take place before the court at a place nearest to where the judgment debtor resides or carries on business.

prov.heading: Certain fees, costs, and expenses incurred by judgment creditor may be recovered

para.text: A judgment creditor may, unless the court or a Registrar otherwise directs, recover from a judgment debtor—
the fees relating to the civil enforcement process against the judgment debtor paid by the judgment creditor in accordance with the regulations that prescribe the fees; and
costs relating to that process in accordance with Schedule 4; and

an amount for expenses incurred for service of documents, if 1 or more documents relating to that process have been served by or on behalf of the judgment creditor, which amount must not exceed the amount prescribed by regulations made under the Act for service by a bailiff.
In rules 19.24 to 19.46, unless the context otherwise requires,—
charging order means an order under section 96A of the Act
judgment creditor means a person who has obtained a judgment or order for the payment of money.
A judgment creditor may apply without notice to the court or a Registrar for a charging order.
The application must—
be in form 49; and
be accompanied by an affidavit in form 50; and
describe the property for which the charging order is sought in sufficient detail so as to identify it.
Section 96A(1A) of the Act specifies which kinds of property may be subject to a charging order.

prov.heading: Filing of application for charging order

para.text: An application for a charging order must not be filed until 48 hours have expired from the time the judgment was entered, or the order was made, unless a Judge gives leave for immediate enforcement.
The Registrar must note on the application and on the charging order the precise time that the application for the charging order was made.
The judgment creditor must prepare and file with the application a draft order and a copy for every person the draft order is intended to affect.
The Registrar must notify the judgment creditor, as soon as practicable after the application has been heard, of the outcome of the hearing.
An application for a charging order may be filed, and a charging order may be made, even if the property to which the application or charging order relates has a value exceeding $200,000.

prov.heading: Charging order where amount involved small

para.text: If the amount involved is so small that the making of a charging order is vexatious or worthless, the court or a Registrar may—
refuse the application for a charging order; or
if the charging order has been made (whether as of right or on application), discharge the charging order.
A charging order must be in form 51, 52, or 53, as appropriate.

prov.heading: Application for relief by persons prejudicially affected

para.text: A person alleging that he or she is prejudicially affected by a charging order may, at any time, apply to the court for relief.
The court may—
vary or discharge the order; or
cancel the registration or modify the effect of registration of any order affecting land.
The powers of the court under this rule are in addition to its powers under rules 2.12 and 11.24.

prov.heading: Claim of third person on property charged

para.text: If it is alleged that land or other property affected by a charging order belongs to a third person, or that a third person has a claim on it by way of lien, charge, or otherwise,—
the Registrar must issue a summons in form 54 together with a copy of it; and
the summons must be served on the third person a reasonable time before the day fixed for the hearing.
If the third person does not appear at the hearing of the matter, the court, on proof of service, may make any order that it thinks fit in the interests of justice.
The third person may, on giving 24 hours’ notice of his or her intention to do so, also attend—
the hearing of an application to make a final charging order; or
the hearing of any application to set aside or vary the charging order.
Despite subclause (3), the Judge may give the third person leave to attend without giving 24 hours’ notice.

prov.heading: Apportionment when more than 1 charging order

para.text: A person against whom more than 1 charging order is made, or who claims to be affected by more than 1 charging order, may apply to the court for an order under subclause (2).
The court may determine how much or what part of the property affected by the charging order is for the separate use of each party who has obtained a charging order.

prov.heading: Charging order final in first instance

para.text: If the property sought to be charged is an estate, right, title, or interest in possession, remainder, reversion, or expectancy, and whether vested or contingent, in any land held by the judgment debtor in that judgment debtor’s own name, the charging order is final in the first instance.

prov.heading: Registration of charging order under Land Transfer Act 1952

para.text: A charging order made under rule 19.32 in respect of land under the Land Transfer Act 1952 must be registered against the certificate of title to the land under that Act.
The charging order—
must—
contain a description of the land affected sufficient to identify that land; or
refer to a certificate of title or other instrument containing such a description; and
must have drawn on it, or annexed to it, a plan of the land showing its extent, boundaries, and relative position, unless the land is—
the whole of the land comprised in a certificate or certificates of title; or
shown separately on a plan deposited under the provisions of the Land Transfer Act 1952.

The judgment creditor must deposit a duplicate of the charging order with the Registrar-General of Land unless the Registrar-General has dispensed with the production of duplicate instruments in accordance with the Land Transfer Act 1952.

prov.heading: Registration of charging order under Deeds Registration Act 1908

para.text: A charging order made under rule 19.32 in respect of land that is not under the Land Transfer Act 1952 must be registered with the Registrar-General of Land.
The charging order—
must contain a description of the land affected, or refer to the Crown grant or other instrument, sufficient to identify that land; and
must have drawn on it, or annexed to it, a plan of the land showing its extent, boundaries, and relative position.

prov.heading: Lodging of charging order under Crown Minerals Act 1991

para.text: A charging order made under rule 19.32 in respect of a mining privilege within the meaning of the Crown Minerals Act 1991 must be registered by lodging it with the Registrar-General of Land.
The charging order—
must either—
contain a description of the land affected sufficient to identify that land; or
refer to a document granting or issuing the mining privilege, or any other instrument by which the mining privilege was acquired, containing such a description; and
must have drawn on it, or annexed to it, a plan of the land showing its extent, boundaries, and relative position, unless the land affected—
comprises the whole of the land to which the mining privilege relates; or
is shown separately on a plan deposited under the Crown Minerals Act 1991.
When the charging order is lodged, a copy of it must be deposited with the chief executive of the department responsible for the administration of the Crown Minerals Act 1991.
The Registrar-General of Land is not required to inquire whether subclause (3) has been complied with.

prov.heading: Sale before registration of charging order

para.text: An unregistered charging order has no effect against a purchaser for valuable consideration.
Subclause (1) applies even if—
the sale order may have been actually delivered for enforcement at the time of purchase; and
the purchaser may have had actual or constructive notice of the delivery of the sale order for enforcement.

prov.heading: Discharge of land or mining privilege from charging order

para.text: The land or mining privilege subject to a charging order is discharged from the charging order on registration with the Registrar-General of Land of—
a memorandum of satisfaction of the judgment in the proceeding in which the charging order has been issued, or other sufficient evidence of satisfaction; or
an order of the court to the effect that the land or mining privilege is discharged from the charging order; or
the consent of the person who registered the charging order to the discharge of the land or mining privilege from the charging order.
A charging order expires 2 years after the date of the charging order unless, before the expiry of that period,—
the charging order is extended under subclause (2); or
the charging order has led to a sale order and a person registers any of the following in relation to the land or mining privilege under that sale order:
an instrument of transfer:
a deed of conveyance:
an assignment.
The court or a Registrar may, if the court or Registrar thinks fit in the interests of justice, extend the 2-year period in any case by any period the court or Registrar considers necessary.
A charging order that has expired ceases to bind the land or mining privilege affected and is treated as having been discharged.

prov.heading: Property other than land that may be charged

para.text: Section 96A(1A) of the Act specifies which kinds of property other than land may be subject to a charging order.
A charging order under rule 19.39—
is a limited charging order until sufficient cause is shown to the contrary; and
is called an interim charging order in this rule and rules 19.41 to 19.44.
An interim charging order must be served on the person it is intended to affect.
If an interim charging order is intended to affect an estate, right, or interest in land held under or because of any trust,—
that interim charging order may also be registered against the land; or
a caveat may be entered in respect of the interim charging order.
A person served with an interim charging order must refrain from—
making, agreeing to, or allowing any conveyance, transfer, assignment, or disposition of any estate, right, or interest, or of any share in a partnership or company, of the judgment debtor; or
paying over any income, interest, dividends, bonus, profits, or other money due or accruing due to the judgment debtor.
However, subclause (1) does not prevent a person from doing any of those things in accordance with these rules or with the leave of the court or a Registrar.

prov.heading: Liability for breach of interim charging order

para.text: The court may order a person who breaches rule 19.41 to pay the judgment creditor—
the amount of money paid, or the value of the property disposed of, in breach of that rule; or
a sufficient part of the money paid to satisfy the judgment or order that the judgment creditor has obtained in the proceeding.
An order made under subclause (1) may be in addition to, or in place of, any penalty that may be imposed under any other rule.

prov.heading: Money may be paid into court

para.text: A person served with an interim charging order may pay into court any money to abide the order of the court.

prov.heading: Application to make interim charging order final

para.text: The judgment creditor may, at any time after obtaining the interim charging order, apply to the court to have the interim charging order made final.
The application must be made on notice and must be in form 55.
The court or a Registrar may make orders and give directions for the disposal of money paid into court under rule 19.43 as the court or Registrar thinks fit in the interests of justice.

part.crosshead: Miscellaneous provisions relating to charging orders

para.text: The judgment creditor may, unless the court or a Registrar otherwise directs, recover from the judgment debtor against whom a charging order has been made the fees, costs, and expenses incurred in respect of, and incidental to, the making of the charging order.

prov.heading: Removal of final charging order to High Court

para.text: A judgment creditor who has obtained a final charging order may apply to a Registrar of the District Court for the removal of that charging order to the High Court in order that the charging order may be enforced in the same way as if it had been issued by the High Court.
On removal of the charging order, the High Court must determine any matter raised relating to the charging order in the same way as if the charging order had been issued by the High Court.

prov.heading: Application for warrant to seize property

para.text: A judgment creditor who wants a warrant to seize property issued must file an application in form 56.
The application must not be filed until 48 hours after judgment has been given, or the order made, unless the Judge gives leave for immediate enforcement.
The Registrar must record the precise time when the application is made to issue the warrant.
If more than 1 warrant to seize property is issued against the same person, the warrants must be executed in the order of the times recorded under rule 19.47(3).
A warrant to seize property—
must be issued by a Registrar in an approved form:
may be addressed to any bailiff or constable.
An unenforced warrant to seize property—
expires 1 year after the date of issue unless it is renewed; and
may be renewed for 1 year, by leave of the court or a Registrar, before the warrant expires; and
may be renewed more than once.
The Registrar must keep a note of every renewal.
A warrant that has been renewed has effect and takes priority according to the time of its original issue.
Enforcement, in the case of a judgment or order against a firm, may issue—
against any property of the partnership:
against any person who has admitted in the proceeding that he or she was a partner when the cause of action arose, or who has been found liable as a partner:
against any person who was individually served with the summons as a partner or a person sought to be made liable if—
judgment was entered against the person on a summary judgment application where the person failed to serve a response or to file and serve a statement of defence; or
the person failed to appear at the hearing (if any).

A party who has obtained a judgment or order, and claims to be entitled to issue enforcement against any other person as a partner, may apply to the court for leave to do so, and the following provisions apply:
the party must give the alleged partner at least 3 working days’ notice of the application:
the notice must be served on the alleged partner personally:
on the hearing of the application, the court may, if liability is not disputed, give leave to issue enforcement:
if liability is disputed, the court may order the issue of liability to be heard in any manner it thinks fit and may give all necessary directions for that purpose.

A judgment against a firm must not render liable, release, or otherwise affect any partner who was out of New Zealand when the summons was issued, unless that partner has been individually served with the summons.
Subclause (3) does not apply to a judgment against the property of the partnership.
Warrants to seize property may be issued concurrently for enforcement in 1 or more registries of the court.
The costs of more than 1 warrant to seize property must not be allowed except by order of the court or a Registrar.

prov.heading: Costs of warrants to seize property

para.text: The costs of warrants to seize property, whether enforced, unenforced, or unproductive, must be allowed against the enforcement debtor unless—
the court or a Registrar otherwise orders; or
these rules provide otherwise.

prov.heading: Holding over enforcement and withdrawing from possession

para.text: At any time before enforcement, the enforcement creditor may require the bailiff to return the warrant to seize property to the court.
If the enforcement creditor requests the bailiff to withdraw from possession,—
the enforcement creditor is, unless subclause (4) applies, treated as having abandoned the enforcement; and
the bailiff must record that the warrant was withdrawn by request of the enforcement creditor.
If the request to withdraw is made in consequence of a claim under rule 19.89 to the seized goods, the enforcement is treated as having been abandoned only in respect of the goods claimed.
The bailiff must record that the warrant was suspended by request of the enforcement creditor, if the enforcement creditor—
requests the bailiff to withdraw from possession; and
at the same time, authorises the bailiff to re-enter by filing an authority in form 57 authenticated by the enforcement debtor.

prov.heading: Reissue of warrant to seize property

para.text: A warrant to seize property that has been returned or suspended under rule 19.53 may not be reissued until after the enforcement creditor applies to a Registrar to reissue the warrant.
If application is made to reissue a warrant,—
the Registrar must record the date and the precise time of the application; and
for the purposes of rules 19.47(3) and 19.48, the reissued warrant is treated as having been applied for at the time so recorded.
Nothing in this rule—
prejudices any right of the enforcement creditor to apply for a fresh warrant; or
authorises the reissue of a warrant that has been withdrawn, has expired, or has been superseded by the issue of a fresh warrant.

A possession fee is not payable if an enforcement is paid out at the time of seizure; but a possession fee is payable if the bailiff, out of necessity, has to place a person in possession of the goods even though enforcement is paid out on the same day.
If goods are seized in enforcement, the bailiff or a Registrar must provide to the enforcement debtor—
a sufficient inventory of the goods seized; and
notice, in form 58, of the time at which, and place where, the goods will be sold.
The inventory and notice must—
be given or sent in any of the ways specified in section 108A(1)﻿(a) to (c) of the Act; or
be left at the place where the goods were seized or sent by post addressed to the enforcement debtor at that place.
The inventory must be given or sent at the time, or immediately after, the goods are seized.
The notice must be given or sent at least 24 hours before the time fixed for the sale.

If goods are sold under an enforcement, the bailiff must, at the request of the enforcement debtor, provide the enforcement debtor with a detailed account of the sale and the application of the proceeds.

prov.heading: Bailiff to furnish statements to Registrar

para.text: The bailiff must deliver to a Registrar immediately after seizure an inventory of all cheques, bills of exchange, promissory notes, bonds, and other securities for money seized or taken by the bailiff under a warrant to seize property.
When returning a warrant after enforcement, the bailiff must also provide—
a copy of the inventory of the goods signed by the bailiff; and
if the goods have been sold,—
a statement setting out opposite each article the price realised at the sale; and
a balance sheet in respect of the proceeds of the warrant and expenses in form 59.
If, after a diligent search, the bailiff cannot find any goods to seize, the bailiff must when returning the warrant, also report in form 60 the outcome of the search.
The Registrar must—
require that the bailiff provide to the Registrar the various statements, reports, and balance sheets required by these rules, accompanied by vouchers for all disbursements; and
examine those documents.
A warrant returned in accordance with subclause (2) or (3) may not be enforced except under rule 19.59.

prov.heading: Court may order enforcement on returned warrant to seize property

para.text: After a warrant is returned in accordance with rule 19.58, the court may order that the warrant be enforced against any goods referred to or specified in the order, if satisfied that—

there are reasonable grounds to believe that the enforcement debtor or any person on behalf of the enforcement debtor has control or possession of goods that could have been seized under the warrant; and
no bankruptcy petition based on the enforcement or on the return has been filed.
If an order is made under subclause (1), the warrant—
continues in force for the purposes of the order; and
has the same duration and the same priority in respect of enforcement as it had under these rules when it was originally issued.
Subclause (1) does not apply to any warrant that would have expired under rule 19.49.
At least 48 hours’ notice must be given on any application under section 89 of the Act for an order that a sale under a warrant to seize property may be made other than by public auction.
Notice must be served on the bailiff and on all other parties having an interest in the enforcement.
The court or a Registrar may direct that the costs of any party attending be paid by any other party, or otherwise as the court or Registrar thinks fit in the interests of justice.
A plaintiff who has obtained a judgment or order for the delivery of specific chattels may apply to a Registrar in form 61.

On receiving the application, the Registrar may issue a warrant in form 62 to the bailiff requiring that the bailiff demand and seize the specific chattels (if they can be found) and deliver them to the plaintiff.
Any application for a warrant of committal to enforce a judgment or order for the delivery of specific chattels must be made and dealt with in accordance with rules 19.66 and 19.67.

prov.heading: Warrant to seize property for value of chattels and for damages, etc

para.text: A plaintiff may apply to the court on notice to fix the value of the chattels if the court has not fixed the value at the hearing.

If possession of chattels has not been obtained under a warrant issued under rule 19.61, a Registrar may, once the value of the chattels has been fixed, issue a warrant to seize property in an approved form, to recover—
the value fixed for the chattels; and
any costs and damages awarded at the hearing for detention (unless separate enforcement has been issued).

Subclause (2) does not prejudice the right of the plaintiff to obtain enforcement, concurrently or at any earlier or later time, for the plaintiff’s costs of suit and any damages awarded to the plaintiff for the detention of the chattels.

prov.heading: Where possession ordered to be taken until security given

para.text: The bailiff must make an inventory and appraisement of goods that the bailiff has taken possession of under any warrant that—
directs the bailiff to take possession of the goods until security is given by some party for the safe keeping of the goods, or for the payment of their value in default of safe keeping; but
does not specify the amount of security.
The amount that the bailiff may receive as a deposit under subclause (3) is—
the amount of the appraisement; or
the amount approved by a Registrar as sufficient security for—
the safe keeping of the goods; and
delivering possession of the goods on request.
On receiving the deposit, the bailiff must relinquish possession of the goods on the condition that the goods must be redelivered to the bailiff on request or held to abide the order of the court.
A plaintiff or judgment creditor who has obtained a judgment or order for the recovery of land may apply to a Registrar in form 63 for a warrant to recover the land.
The Registrar may issue a warrant in form 64 for the recovery of land after the expiry of the day on which the defendant is required, by the judgment, to give possession of the land.
An amount due under a judgment given in the proceeding for rent, mesne profits, damages, or costs may be recovered under a warrant in form 64 or by a warrant to seize property.

prov.heading: Judgment or order enforceable by committal

para.text: This rule applies to a judgment or order that is—
enforceable by committal; and
made for the benefit of one party (the applicant) against another party (the respondent); and
in the nature of an injunction.
The Registrar must issue a copy of the judgment or order endorsed with a notice in form 65—
at the time the judgment or order is drawn up; or
in any other case, at the request of the applicant.
The endorsed copy of the judgment or order must be served on the respondent in the manner required under rule 6.11 (Personal service).
If the respondent fails to obey the judgment or order referred to in rule 19.66,—

a Registrar, at the request of the applicant, must issue a notice in form 66 not less than 2 working days after the date of service of the endorsed copy of the judgment or order, unless the Judge gives leave for the notice to be issued sooner; and
the notice must be served on the respondent in the manner required under rule 6.11 (Personal service).
On the day named in the notice, the Judge may order a warrant of committal to be issued if satisfied that—
the respondent has failed to obey the judgment or order; and
if the respondent does not appear, the endorsed copy of the judgment or order and the notice have been served on the respondent.
The order for the issue of the warrant must be in form 67, and the warrant, which must be signed by the Registrar, must be in form 68.
A copy of the order must be served on the respondent either before or at the time the warrant is executed, unless the Judge otherwise orders.
A person in custody under a warrant who wishes to apply for discharge must—
file an affidavit specifying the grounds on which he or she applies for discharge; and

not less than 24 hours before the application is made, serve on the party (if any) at whose instance the warrant of committal was issued a copy of the affidavit and a notice of his or her intention to make the application.
If the order of committal directs that the application for discharge must be made to the Judge, it may be made at any place appointed by the Judge.
