If the order of committal does not direct that the application must be made to the Judge, it may be made to a Registrar.
The order for discharge must be in form 69.

prov.heading: Release on bail pending hearing of application for discharge from custody

para.text: A person intending to apply for discharge from custody under rule 19.68(1) may, at the time the affidavit under rule 19.68(1)﻿(a) is filed, apply to the Judge to be released on bail pending the hearing of the application for discharge from custody.
An application under rule 19.68(1) must be served on the party (if any) at whose instance the warrant of committal was issued at the same time as the affidavit under rule 19.68(1)﻿(a) is served.
The order for release on bail under this rule may be made subject to any conditions that the Judge may impose.
In this rule and rules 19.71 to 19.88, unless the context otherwise requires,—
judgment creditor means a person who has obtained a judgment or order for the payment of money
judgment debtor means the person against whom a judgment or order for the payment of money has been made
sub-debtor means a person against whom a garnishee order is made or sought in respect of any debt owing from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor.
A judgment creditor may take a garnishee proceeding in accordance with rules 19.72 to 19.88.
A garnishee proceeding may be taken even if the amount of debt owing or accruing from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor exceeds $200,000.
A garnishee proceeding is started by the judgment creditor filing an affidavit in form 70.
On the filing of the affidavit, the Registrar must issue a garnishee summons to the sub-debtor in form 71 and a notice to the judgment debtor in form 72.
At least 15 working days before the day of the hearing,—
the summons must be served on the sub-debtor personally; and
the notice must be served on the judgment debtor personally.
When it is served on the sub-debtor, the summons binds in the hands of the sub-debtor as much of the debt owing or accruing from the sub-debtor to the judgment creditor as will satisfy—
the debt due under the judgment or order; and
the costs entered on the summons.

prov.heading: Statement to be filed by sub-debtor in respect of deposit or other accounts

para.text: This rule applies if—
the debt alleged to be due from the sub-debtor comprises a sum that—
stands to the credit of the judgment debtor with the sub-debtor; and
is on deposit with the sub-debtor or is held by the sub-debtor in a current or other account (for example, a deposit account); and
it is a condition of the deposit or account that a deposit book, receipt for money paid, or other like document must be produced before any money is withdrawn.
When this rule applies, the sub-debtor must, as soon as practicable after being served with the summons, and at least 3 working days before the date of hearing,—
file a statement in form 73 in the court office; and
serve that statement on the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor.
The sub-debtor may, at any time before the day of the hearing, pay into court—
the amount admitted to be due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor; or
if the amount admitted is more than sufficient to satisfy the amount due under the judgment or order and the costs entered on the summons, a sum sufficient to satisfy that amount and those costs.
The sub-debtor is treated as having been discharged from the proceeding if—
the amount admitted to be due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor is less than the amount claimed owing under the summons; and
the judgment creditor files in the court and serves on the judgment debtor and sub-debtor a notice that the judgment creditor accepts the amount.

prov.heading: Payment out of court of money paid by sub-debtor

para.text: Money paid into court by the sub-debtor may be paid out to the judgment creditor before the day of hearing by a Registrar on production of the written consent of the judgment debtor.

In the absence of the judgment debtor’s written consent, the court may, on the day of the hearing, after hearing the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor, if they appear, make any order in the proceedings, including an order for costs, that it thinks fit in the interests of justice.

prov.heading: Garnishee order where sub-debtor does not pay into court or appear

para.text: The court may make an order under subclause (2) if—
the sub-debtor does not, before the day of the hearing, pay into court—
the amount admitted to be due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor or an amount sufficient to satisfy that part of the judgment or order that is unsatisfied; and
the costs entered on the garnishee summons; and
the sub-debtor does not, on the day of the hearing, appear and dispute the debt alleged to be due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor; and
the judgment debtor does not appear on the day of the hearing and show cause to the contrary.
If subclause (1) applies, the court may order the sub-debtor to pay the judgment creditor—
the amount due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor or an amount sufficient to satisfy the judgment or order against the judgment debtor; and
costs.
A garnishee order made under this rule—
must be entered in the court records:
may be enforced as a judgment of the court.
A sub-debtor who wishes to dispute liability must, within 5 working days after the service of the summons on the sub-debtor inclusive of the day of service,—
file, without fee, in the court office a notice in form 74; and
serve a copy of the notice on the judgment creditor and the judgment debtor.

If notice has been given to the judgment creditor under subclause (1) or the amount paid into court under rule 19.76 is not accepted, the court may, after hearing the judgment creditor, the sub-debtor, and the judgment debtor, or any of them that appear, make an order referred to in subclause (3).
The court may—

determine the liability of the sub-debtor, and make any order as to the payment to the judgment creditor of any sum found to be due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor, and costs, that it thinks fit in the interests of justice; or

order that any issue necessary for determining the question of the liability of the sub-debtor be tried in a manner that the court thinks fit, and direct which of the persons interested, including any third party referred to in rule 19.80, is to be the plaintiff and which is to be the defendant; or
order that the judgment creditor be at liberty to sue the sub-debtor for—
the amount alleged to be due by the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor, if the amount alleged is less than the judgment debt; or
the amount of the judgment debt with costs of suit, if the amount alleged to be due by the sub-debtor or to the judgment creditor is greater than the judgment debt.
An order for payment made under this rule may be enforced as a judgment of the court.
No order may be made under this rule if the sub-debtor disputes the debt and the debt claimed exceeds $200,000.
At any time before the hearing, the sub-debtor may apply to the court for an order that—

the garnishee proceeding be transferred, under subpart 1 of Part 5, to a registry of the court in which it could have been started if it were a proceeding brought against the sub-debtor by the judgment debtor to recover the debt; or
the garnishee proceeding be referred to a Registrar for inquiry and report under Part 16.
The court may make any order in respect of an application under subclause (6) that it thinks fit in the interests of justice.

prov.heading: Where debt stated to belong to third party

para.text: If it is suggested in a garnishee proceeding that the debt belongs to or is claimed by a third party, or that a party has or claims to have a lien or charge on it, the court may order the third party to appear and state the nature and particulars of his or her claim to the debt.
After hearing the third party, if that third party appears, the court may—
bar the claim of the third party; or
order an issue to be heard between the third party and the judgment creditor; or
make any other order, including an order for costs, that it thinks fit in the interests of justice.

prov.heading: Garnishee orders in respect of deposit and other accounts

para.text: This rule applies if—
a garnishee order is sought in respect of a sum that—
stands to the credit of the judgment debtor with the sub-debtor (for example, a bank or savings bank); and
is on deposit with the sub-debtor or held by the sub-debtor in a current or other account (for example, a deposit account); and
it is a condition of the deposit or account that a document must be produced before any money is withdrawn.

If it appears to the court that any document must be produced, the court may, by order in form 75, require any person (including the judgment debtor) who has possession or knows the whereabouts of the document to—
deliver it to the court within 5 working days after the date of service of the order on that person or within any other time that the court specifies in the order; or
disclose its whereabouts to the court within that time.
The judgment creditor may apply without notice for an order under subclause (2).
A person against whom an order is made under subclause (2) must, within 5 working days after the date of service of the order,—
file in court an affidavit in form 76; and
serve a copy of the affidavit on the judgment creditor.
The Registrar, subject to any directions of the court, must—
produce to the sub-debtor any document delivered to the court under subclause (2); and
retain the document until the garnishee proceeding is disposed of, unless the sub-debtor pays into court the full amount in respect of which an order is sought.

prov.heading: Discharge of sub-debtor as against judgment debtor

para.text: Payment made by or enforcement levied on the sub-debtor under a garnishee proceeding is a valid discharge to the sub-debtor (to the amount paid or levied), as against the judgment debtor, even if the proceeding is later set aside or the judgment or order is reversed.
However, subclause (1) does not apply to the payment or enforcement of costs ordered to be paid by the sub-debtor personally.
The court may hear evidence about the circumstances of the judgment debtor.

If it appears to the court that the judgment debtor reasonably requires all or part of the money sought to be attached for the maintenance and support of the judgment debtor and his or her family, the court may—
refuse to make a garnishee order; and
make an order as to the disposal of any money paid.
The court may refuse to make a garnishee order if, in its opinion, the amount to be recovered or the debt sought to be attached is too small.

prov.heading: Where money due by sub-debtor under judgment or order

para.text: This rule applies to any amount due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor under a judgment or order obtained by the judgment debtor against the sub-debtor.

The sub-debtor, unless the court otherwise orders, is not liable to pay the judgment creditor the amount due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor by any larger instalments than those that the sub-debtor is liable to pay to the judgment debtor under the judgment or order.
The Registrar must enter in the court records relating to the judgment or order a note of—
the amounts paid or ordered to be paid by the sub-debtor in the garnishee proceeding, other than costs ordered to be paid by the sub-debtor personally:
any costs that the sub-debtor may, by order of the court, deduct from the amount due from the sub-debtor to the judgment debtor.
If money is standing to the credit of the judgment debtor in the court, the judgment creditor—
cannot take a garnishee proceeding in respect of that money; but
may apply to the court on notice for an order that the money, or the amount of it necessary to satisfy the judgment debt and costs, be paid to the judgment creditor.
On receipt of notice of the application, the Registrar must retain the money in court until the application has been heard.
On the hearing of the application, the court—
may make any order as to the money in court that it thinks fit in the interests of justice; and
must have regard to the matters mentioned in rule 19.83.
A note of the order must be made in the court records relating to the money standing to the credit of the judgment debtor.
Rules 19.72 to 19.88 apply to debts owing by or accruing from a firm carrying on business in New Zealand, although 1 or more members of the firm may be resident outside New Zealand.
The court may award costs to any sub-debtor attending under rules 19.72 to 19.88, or attending to give evidence under rules 9.17 to 9.24.
If, within a reasonable time, the judgment creditor fails to give notice under rule 19.76(2)﻿(b), the court may award the sub-debtor the costs incurred by the sub-debtor at the hearing.
The court may also award costs to a judgment debtor attending to give evidence in a garnishee proceeding—
if the proceeding is abandoned by the judgment creditor; or
for any other reason that the court thinks sufficient.
No fee is payable in respect of any order of the court for the payment out of court of any money paid into court in any garnishee proceeding.

Any costs allowed to the judgment creditor that are not ordered to be paid by the sub-debtor personally, unless it is otherwise ordered, are to be retained by the judgment creditor out of money recovered by the judgment creditor in the garnishee proceeding, in priority to the amount due under the judgment or order.
In the case of a garnishee proceeding against the Crown as a sub-debtor, rules 19.72 to 19.87 apply with the following modifications:
rules 19.72 to 19.87 do not apply to any debt that is excepted by the proviso to section 26 of the Crown Proceedings Act 1950:
the affidavit required under rule 19.73 must be filed, and must give, in addition to the particulars prescribed by form 70, particulars of—
the circumstances in which it is alleged that the liability of the Crown has arisen; and
the government department or officer of the Crown concerned:

the garnishee summons to be served on the sub-debtor under rule 19.74 must be served on the Crown, together with a copy of the affidavit filed in support of the summons, not less than 35 working days before the day of the hearing:
the time within which the sub-debtor must, under rule 19.79(1), file a notice to dispute the debt claimed is 30 working days:
rules 19.78(3)﻿(b) and 19.79(4) have effect subject to section 24 of the Crown Proceedings Act 1950.

part.crosshead: Third party claim process relating to enforcement

para.text: Any claim under section 93 of the Act to or in respect of the goods seized in enforcement must—
be in form 77; and
be provided to the bailiff holding the seized property.
The bailiff must lodge the claim in a registry of the court.
On receipt of the claim, the Registrar must notify the enforcement creditor in form 78.
If the value of any goods claimed is disputed, the Registrar may—
at the request of the claimant, appoint a person to fix by appraisement the value of the goods; and
fix the remuneration to be paid for the appraisement.
The claimant must pay into court the remuneration fixed by the Registrar, which must be paid to the appraiser.
The Registrar may revoke the appointment of any appraiser and appoint another person in his or her place.
The remuneration fixed for the appraiser may, if the court so orders, be costs in the third party claim process.
If, in form 79, the enforcement creditor notifies the Registrar that the enforcement creditor admits the title of the claimant, or requests that the bailiff withdraw from possession,—
the Registrar must notify the bailiff immediately; and
the proceeding is stayed; and
the enforcement creditor is not liable to the bailiff for any possession fees or expenses incurred after the bailiff was notified by the Registrar.

The Judge may, on application by the bailiff on not less than 1 working day’s notification to the enforcement creditor, order the enforcement creditor to pay any fees or expenses for which the enforcement creditor is liable.
If the enforcement creditor notifies the Registrar in accordance with rule 19.92(1), the bailiff—
must withdraw from possession; and
may apply to the Judge, on not less than 1 working day’s notification to the claimant, for an order protecting the bailiff from any action in respect of the seizure and possession of the goods.
On the hearing of the application under subclause (1)﻿(b), the Judge may make any order he or she thinks fit in the interests of justice.
If the enforcement creditor does not give notification in accordance with rule 19.92(1), the Registrar must, at the request of the bailiff,—
fix a day for the hearing; and
serve summonses in any of forms 80 to 83 (that apply to the case) on the enforcement creditor and the claimant.
Subclause (1) does not apply if the claimant has withdrawn his or her claim.
A summons under rule 19.94 must be served not less than 7 working days before the day of the hearing.

prov.heading: Security for costs where claimant does not reside in New Zealand

para.text: If it appears that the claimant does not reside in New Zealand, the enforcement creditor may apply to the Judge on not less than 1 working day’s notification for an order directing the claimant to give security for costs.
A claimant who fails to comply with an order under subclause (1) is not entitled to be heard in support of his or her claim, unless the Judge otherwise orders.

prov.heading: Particulars and grounds of claim to be lodged

para.text: The claimant must serve on the enforcement creditor, and file in the registry of the court dealing with the third party claim, particulars of any goods alleged to be the claimant’s property and of the grounds for his or her claim to the goods.
The claimant must serve and file the particulars—
within 3 working days after the service of the summons on the claimant inclusive of the day of service; or
if the time for service has been shortened, within such reasonable time before the day of the hearing as the time of service allows.
The claimant must include in the particulars a statement of his or her full name, address, and occupation.
This rule applies if, before the day of the hearing,—
the claimant serves on the enforcement creditor and files in the registry of the court dealing with the third party claim a notice that the claimant withdraws his or her claim; or
the enforcement creditor serves on the claimant and files in the office of that court an admission of the title of the claimant.
When this rule applies,—
the goods seized, or the proceeds of the sale, or the money paid into court, as the case may be, must be dealt with as if the claim had not been made or the enforcement had been withdrawn; and
the Judge may make any order for costs, fees, charges, and expenses that he or she thinks fit in the interests of justice.

If, in the third party claim process, a claimant claims damages from the enforcement creditor or from the bailiff in respect of the seizure of the goods, the claimant must state, in the particulars of his or her claim to the goods,—
the amount claimed for damages; and
the grounds on which those damages are claimed.

prov.heading: Claim for damages by enforcement creditor

para.text: If, in the third party claim process, the enforcement creditor claims damages against the bailiff arising out of the enforcement, the enforcement creditor must, within the time limited by rule 19.97(2),—
give the bailiff notice of his or her claim, stating the grounds and amount of the claim; and
file the notice in the registry of the court dealing with the third party claim.

prov.heading: Payment into court where damages claimed

para.text: If, in the third party claim process, the claimant claims damages from the bailiff or from the enforcement creditor, or the enforcement creditor claims damages from the bailiff,—
the person from whom damages are claimed may pay money into court to satisfy that claim; and

the payment must be made in the same manner and has the same effect as if the person claiming damages were the plaintiff in a proceeding and the person from whom damages are claimed were the defendant.
An application for a writ of arrest and an affidavit in support of it must be in form 84.
The applicant must deposit a sum that the Judge or a Registrar thinks reasonable to cover the costs and expenses of arrest.
The costs and expenses of arrest are costs in the proceeding.
A writ of arrest must be in form 85, and may be addressed to any bailiff or constable.
The bailiff or constable must, on executing the writ, deliver to the defendant a notice, signed by the Judge or a Registrar, in form 86.
If the defendant gives bail for his or her attendance at the hearing, it may be by bond in form 87.
In default of bail being given, the warrant of remand may be in form 88.
If the defendant consents to a summary hearing, the consent may be in form 89.

part.crosshead: Proceedings by and against executors and administrators

prov.heading: Costs where executor sues and fails

para.text: If the plaintiff in a proceeding is an executor or administrator and the plaintiff fails, any costs awarded to the defendant must, unless the court otherwise orders, be levied on the goods of the plaintiff.

prov.heading: Judgment and enforcement against executor or administrator

para.text: If the court gives judgment against an executor or administrator sued in his or her capacity as an executor or administrator, the judgment must record that it is given against the defendant in that capacity.
Enforcement on the judgment is, subject to this rule, limited to assets of the estate of the deceased in the hands of the executor or administrator.

If the executor or administrator satisfies the court that he or she has no assets, or insufficient assets, in his or her hands to satisfy the claim, the court may give judgment that the amount, or as the case may require, the balance of the amount, be levied on the assets of the estate that, from then on, come into the hands of the executor or administrator.

If the executor or administrator unnecessarily denies the claim or unsuccessfully alleges that he or she has no assets, then, in addition to the other remedies available, the court may order that the amount awarded for costs be levied against the executor or administrator personally.
If judgment has been given under rule 19.105(3),—
the plaintiff may apply to the court on notice for an order in respect of the assets in question; and
the court may make an order in form 90 if it appears that, since judgment, any assets of the estate have come into the hands of the executor or administrator.
A copy of the order must be served on the executor or administrator.

part.crosshead: Miscellaneous provisions relating to transmission and authentication of documents, etc

para.text: The following provisions apply for the purposes of this Part and Part 6 of the Act:
a requirement to send or provide a document or notification is met if the document is delivered, left, or sent in any of the ways specified in section 108A(1)﻿(a) to (c) of the Act:
a record of anything that is required to be kept or made may be kept or made by electronic means:

a document or notification may be sent, given, provided, or made by electronic means if the recipient has provided a compatible address for service for the purposes of receiving the document or notification by electronic means.
The following provisions of Part 6 (service) apply for the purposes of this Part:
rule 6.2 (service of copies):
rule 6.7 (service under agreement):
rule 6.8 (substituted service):
rule 6.9 (notices to be given by Registrar):
rule 6.16 (personal service on unincorporated societies):
rule 6.17 (personal service on partnership or apparent partnership):
rule 6.26 (service of other documents outside New Zealand):
rule 6.29 (service through official channels):
rule 6.30 (service in convention countries).
The following provisions of Part 6 do not apply for the purposes of this Part:
rule 6.1 (methods of service):
rule 6.4 (personal service on spouses or partners):
rule 6.5 (service at address for service):
rule 6.6 (service by means of post office box, document exchange, fax, or email):
rule 6.10 (proof of service):
rule 6.11 (personal service):
rule 6.12 (personal service on New Zealand corporations):
rule 6.13 (personal service in New Zealand on foreign corporations):
rule 6.14 (personal service on Australian corporations, partnerships, and attorneys):
rule 6.15 (personal service in Australia on foreign corporations):
rule 6.18 (personal service on attorney or agent of absentee):
rule 6.19 (service on representatives):
rule 6.20 (service on solicitor):
rule 6.21 (service of statement of claim on certain days void):
rule 6.22 (failure to give address for service):
rules 6.23 to 6.25 (service outside New Zealand):
rule 6.27 (notice to defendant served outside New Zealand):
rule 6.28 (service outside New Zealand):
rule 6.31 (time for filing defence).
This rule overrides Part 6.
A document filed in the court must be authenticated by the person responsible for its content.
A document issued or sent by the court that is not sealed must be authenticated by a judicial officer or by an officer of the court who is authorised to do so.
A person responsible for the content of a document authenticates the document by—
signing and dating the document; or
any means that adequately identifies that person and the date of authentication.
A warrant may be authenticated in the manner provided in subclause (3) or by a Registrar entering the particulars of the warrant into a computer system accessible to a constable or a bailiff.

part.heading: Applications in equity and under statutes

subpart.heading: Special cases

para.text: This Part applies to—
proceedings in which the relief claimed is wholly within the equitable jurisdiction of the court:
any proceeding by a person affected by a mortgage or charge (whether legal or equitable) of an interest in land for the purpose of determining—
the person's rights or obligations under the mortgage or charge; or
the exercise or purported or threatened exercise of any right or power alleged to arise out of the mortgage or charge:
any other proceeding to which the court directs that this Part applies.

prov.heading: Application of this Part to proceedings under Industrial and Provident Societies Act 1908

para.text: This Part also applies to proceedings in which the relief is claimed solely under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act 1908 but subject to any rules of the relevant society made under that Act.

Nothing in this rule prevents a person who is otherwise able to claim relief by filing an originating application under Part 6 from doing so, but in that case nothing in this Part applies to that proceeding.

prov.heading: This Part subject to rules under other Acts

para.text: The application of this Part to a proceeding brought under an Act is subject to any rules in force under that Act.
A proceeding under this Part must be—
commenced by statement of claim; and
accompanied by an application for directions as to service under rule 20.7.

The application of this Part to a proceeding does not prevent the commencement of that proceeding by originating application if it is eligible to be so commenced under subpart 2 of this Part, in which event this Part does not apply.
Rule 1.9, with all necessary modifications, applies to a proceeding under this Part.

subpart.crosshead: Special provisions concerning pleadings, directions, and affidavits

prov.heading: Naming of defendants in cases involving deceased estates or trusts

para.text: This rule applies to a proceeding that—
involves a deceased estate or a trust; and
is not commenced by the personal representative of the deceased person or the trustee of the trust.
The only defendant that may be named in the statement of claim is the personal representative or the trustee.

prov.heading: Persons served by direction of court need not be named as defendant

para.text: A person who becomes a defendant to a proceeding by being served under a direction of the court made under rule 20.8 need not be named as defendant.

prov.heading: Applications for directions as to service

para.text: This rule applies when—
the law requires the making of an application for directions as to service; or
the plaintiff is in doubt regarding the persons on whom the statement of claim should be served; or
an order is sought that any person represent any other person or class of persons who should be served; or
the court directs that the plaintiff should apply to the court under this rule.
The plaintiff must apply to the court without notice for directions as to service and for any orders for representation that may be required.

In support of the application, the plaintiff must provide (by affidavit or otherwise) the information that may be necessary to enable the court to decide what persons or classes of persons are interested in, or may be adversely affected by, the relief sought by the plaintiff and by what means the interests of each such person or class of persons may be adequately represented.
The application must specify the directions sought and be accompanied by a memorandum by the plaintiff’s solicitor or counsel stating why the directions are sought.

prov.heading: Orders giving directions as to service

para.text: On an application under rule 20.7, the Judge may make any orders for service or representation that the Judge thinks just.

If, in a proceeding involving an incapacitated person or a minor, the Judge considers it is not necessary to appoint a litigation guardian, the Judge may make orders with regard to the representation of that person, without the appointment of a litigation guardian under rule 4.35.
Every order for directions as to service or for representation made under this rule must be set out in the notice of proceeding in accordance with rule 5.26.
This rule applies to a statement of claim that need not be served because of an enactment or a direction of a Judge.

The facts alleged in the statement of claim must be verified by or on behalf of the plaintiff by an affidavit (which may be appended to the statement of claim or filed separately) stating that, so far as they relate to matters within the personal knowledge of the person making the affidavit, they are true, and, so far as they relate to matters not within that person’s personal knowledge, the person believes them to be true.
Despite subclause (2), the Judge may require any fact not within the personal knowledge of the person to be proved by the affidavit of a person who has such personal knowledge.

prov.heading: Time for serving affidavit in support of appearance

para.text: If a defendant in any proceeding to which this Part applies files an appearance in lieu of a statement of defence, the defendant may, at the time of serving the defendant’s appearance, without leave, and at any time afterwards with leave of the court, serve the defendant’s affidavits in support of any matters referred to in the appearance.
These rules apply to affidavits filed under subclause (1) as though they were affidavits filed by a plaintiff in support of a statement of claim.

prov.heading: Statement of defence to be filed

para.text: No affidavit may be filed by a defendant in opposition to the claim of the plaintiff unless the defendant has filed and served a statement of defence to the claim or an appearance.
Affidavits filed by any party after a statement of defence or appearance has been filed must be confined to matters put in issue by pleadings or by the appearance.
Subclause (1) is subject to rule 20.10.

prov.heading: Evidence generally by agreed statement of facts or affidavit

para.text: Unless a Judge otherwise directs, evidence in a proceeding to which this Part applies must be given—
by means of an agreed statement of facts in accordance with rule 9.48; or
by affidavit in accordance with rules 9.58 to 9.79.
Unless a Judge otherwise directs, evidence must be given orally in a proceeding in which relief by way of specific performance is sought.
Subclause (1) applies to a proceeding in respect of which a direction has been given under subclause (2).
An application to the court under any of the following enactments must be filed as an originating application under this subpart:
sections 3, 8, 12, 13, and 20 of the Adoption Act 1955:
sections 8, 9, 19, and 20, of the Alcoholism and Drug Addiction Act 1966:
Arbitration Act 1996 (other than a proceeding to enforce an award by way of action—see rule 20.101):
section 72A of the Arms Act 1983:
Auctioneers Act 1928:
sections 126, 130, 156, 158, 227, 330, and 381 of the Building Act 2004:
section 62 of the Civil Aviation Act 1990:
Criminal Proceeds (Recovery) Act 2009:
sections 9 and 10 of the Criminal Records (Clean Slate) Act 2004:
sections 52, 58(1), and 78(1) of the Crown Minerals Act 1991:
section 23(3) of the Defamation Act 1992:
sections 95D, 96, and 180 of the Electoral Act 1993:
Fencing Act 1978:
section 32 of the Gas Act 1992:
Part 3A and section 126 of the Health Act 1956:
section 105 of the Land Transport Act 1998:
section 12 of the Layby Sales Act 1971:
section 18(2)﻿(c) of the Marriage Act 1955:
section 14(4) of the Mental Health (Compulsory Assessment and Treatment) Act 1992:
sections 9, 12, and 16 of the Minors’ Contracts Act 1969:
sections 313 to 318, 332 to 343, and 357 of the Property Law Act 2007:
Secondhand Dealers and Pawnbrokers Act 2004:
sections 153(1), 154(1), 157(1)﻿(b), 158(1), 159(1), 160(2)﻿(c), and 163(1) of the Search and Surveillance Act 2012:
An application to the court under an enactment that expressly provides for the application to be made by originating application must be filed as an originating application under this subpart.

A party may apply without notice for permission to start a proceeding by originating application under this subpart, and the court may, if the court thinks just, permit the proceeding to start in that way. The proposed originating application must be filed with the application for permission.
This subpart applies to any originating application subject to the Act under which the application is made and any regulations or rules made under that Act.

Despite subclause (1)﻿(c), a second or subsequent application to the court under the Arbitration Act 1996 concerning the same arbitration, whether brought by the plaintiff or the defendant, must be made by interlocutory application in the same proceeding as the first application.

history.history-note: Rule 20.13(1)﻿(o): amended, on 4 January 2017, by section 20(1) of the Health (Protection) Amendment Act 2016 (2016 No 35).
Rule 20.13(1)﻿(x): revoked, on 4 January 2017, by section 20(2) of the Health (Protection) Amendment Act 2016 (2016 No 35).

para.text: A proceeding that may be commenced by originating application is commenced when the originating application is filed in the proper registry, as determined under rule 5.1, or when the court gives permission under rule 20.13(3).

prov.heading: Memorandum relating to filing and address for service

para.text: At the end of the originating application there must be a memorandum stating the matters set out in rule 5.47.
The memorandum may be in the form of one of the paragraphs of the statements in HCF G 10.
The heading of a document presented for filing in a proceeding commenced by originating application must be in HCF G 1.
However, if there is neither a defendant nor a respondent to the proceeding, the heading must be in the following form:

row.entry: In the matter of [title of Act]
In the matter of [full name, place of residence, occupation]

prov.heading: Application of rules relating to interlocutory applications

para.text: The following rules concerning interlocutory applications apply with all necessary modifications to proceedings commenced by originating application:
rule 7.12 (contents, form, and filing of interlocutory application):
rule 7.13 (affidavit to be filed with application):
rule 7.14 (filing by post):
rule 7.15 (service of application and supporting affidavit):
rule 7.16 (application without notice):
rule 7.17 (notice of opposition to application):
rule 7.18 (affidavit to be filed with notice of opposition):
rule 7.19 (affidavit in reply):
rule 7.22 (rules governing affidavits):
rule 7.23 (statements of belief in affidavits):
rule 7.33 (failure to attend):
rule 7.35 (adjournment):
rule 7.38 (interlocutory orders may be made subject to conditions):
rule 7.39 (determination of application without notice):
rule 7.40 (drawing up and sealing interlocutory order).
Subclause (1) is subject to the rules in this Part.
Despite subclause (1), rule 7.38, in its application to a proceeding commenced by originating application, is subject to the Act under which the originating application is made.

prov.heading: Directions as to parties and conduct of applications

para.text: Rule 1.9 applies, with all necessary modifications, to an originating application.
Despite rules 7.13 and 7.18, in a proceeding commenced by originating application, evidence may be taken orally on oath if the court, on application before or at the hearing, so directs.
Rule 9.64 applies to a proceeding commenced by originating application.

prov.heading: Applications for directions as to service

para.text: Rules 20.6 and 20.7 apply to originating applications.

subpart.heading: Proceedings under Harassment Act 1997

para.text: This subpart applies to proceedings under the Harassment Act 1997.
In this subpart, unless the context otherwise requires,—
Act means the Harassment Act 1997
associated respondent means—
a person against whom a restraining order applies as a result of a direction under section 18 of the Act; or
a person against whom a direction under section 18 of the Act is sought
interlocutory application does not include a main application, but includes an application that is ancillary to a main application
main application means—
an application, under section 9 of the Act, for a restraining order:
an application, under section 22 of the Act, for a variation of a restraining order:
an application, under section 23 of the Act, for a discharge of a restraining order
protected person means a person for whose protection a restraining order is made.
This subpart must be construed so as to—
ensure that the object of the Act (as set out in section 6) is attained; and
secure the just, speedy, simple, and inexpensive determination of proceedings under the Act.
This subpart prevails over any inconsistent practice in any proceeding under the Act.

When a Judge hears or determines a proceeding under the Act, the Judge may from time to time give directions that are not inconsistent with the Act or this subpart and that the Judge thinks proper for regulating the business of the court over which he or she presides.

prov.heading: Application of rules in other Parts

para.text: The following rules do not apply to proceedings under the Act:
rule 1.11 (which relates to cases not provided for):
rule 4.37 (which relates to notifications of certain appointments):
rule 4.38 (which sets out the powers of a litigation guardian):
rule 4.56 (which relates to striking out and adding parties):
rule 5.1 (which is about how to determine the proper registry):
rule 5.2 (which provides for transfers from the District Court to the High Court):
rules 5.14 to 5.16 (which are about headings of court documents):
rules 5.24 to 5.27 (which provide for various notices):
rule 5.69 (which relates to extension of time for service):
rule 5.70 (which relates to notice of service to the Registrar):
rules 6.1 to 6.9 (which are about service):
rule 6.11 (which relates to personal service):
rules 7.1 to 7.4 (which are about case management and judicial settlement conferences):
rule 7.5 (which is about additional case management conferences):
rule 7.7 (which relates to cancellation of a case management conference):
rule 7.45 (which relates to applications for an injunction):
rules 8.1 to 8.46 (which are about discovery, inspection, and interrogatories):
rules 10.1 to 10.8 (which are about the mode of trial):
Part 12 (which relates to summary judgment).
Unless excluded by subclause (1), the provisions of a rule in another Part apply to proceedings under the Act so far as they are applicable and with the necessary modifications.
The court must apply subclause (2) and the provisions of a rule to which subclause (2) applies in the manner the court thinks best calculated to—
ensure that the object of the Act (as set out in section 6) is attained; and
promote the ends of justice.
The court may give directions with respect to the procedure and practice to be followed in a particular case if the court is satisfied, in the circumstances of the particular case,—
that the provisions of the Act, or of these rules, or the practice of the court, do not make adequate provision for procedure or practice; or
that difficulties have arisen or doubt exists as to the appropriate procedure or practice.
The directions must in the opinion of the court be necessary to—
ensure that the object of the Act (as set out in section 6) is attained; and
promote the ends of justice.
Any form authorised or directed to be used by this Part may be varied if the circumstances of a particular case require.
Without limiting the generality of subclause (1),—

if a form authorised or directed to be used by this Part contains or specifies material that is inapplicable in the circumstances of a particular case, that material may be deleted or omitted from the completed form:

if a form authorised or directed to be used by this Part contains explanatory material intended only for the information of a particular person, that material need not be included in a copy of the form that is required to be served on or given to another person to whom that material is not relevant.

If these rules do not authorise or direct the use of a particular form, the parties or the court may devise an appropriate form, using forms that are authorised or directed to be used by these rules as guides.
An application, notice, or order must have, on the first page, a general heading (which may be in form 91) that shows—
the registry of the court in which the application or other matter is proceeding; and
the distinguishing number of the application or other matter; and
the name of the Act; and
subject to subclause (2) and rule 20.35, the full name, address, and occupation of each party, so far as they are known to the party presenting the document for filing.

Unless any form authorised or directed to be used under these rules otherwise requires, and subject to rule 20.35, all other documents that are filed, issued, or served in a proceeding under the Act must have on the first page a general heading that complies with subclause (1), except that, in a case in which it is not necessary to distinguish between 2 or more persons,—
given names may be indicated by initials only:
addresses and occupations may be omitted.
A proceeding under the Act must be started by filing a main application in the proper registry, as determined by rule 20.37.
A main application must be made on notice to every person intended to be affected by the order sought by the application.
An application for a restraining order must be in form 92.
An application, under section 22 of the Act, for a variation of a restraining order must be in form 93.
An application, under section 23 of the Act, for a discharge of a restraining order must be in form 93.
A main application must be accompanied by—
a notice of proceeding in form 94, which must be signed by the applicant or the applicant’s solicitor or counsel; and
an affidavit by or on behalf of the applicant, and containing (where applicable) the matters specified in rule 20.33.

A copy of a restraining order that is to be used in support of a main application filed in another court, or a copy of a copy of the restraining order, must be filed with the main application unless the Registrar otherwise directs.
An affidavit accompanying a main application must set out the matters on which the application is based.
An affidavit accompanying an application for a restraining order must contain sufficient particulars to—
show the grounds on which the applicant claims to be entitled to the order; and
inform the court of the facts relied on in support of the application.
An affidavit to which subclause (2) relates must, in particular,—
indicate the nature and history of the harassment that the applicant alleges the respondent has engaged in, including—
an outline of the current situation or most recent incident; and
an outline of the behaviour that forms part of a pattern of behaviour from which protection is needed; and
details of any contact with Police about the behaviour from which protection is needed; and
show why special conditions are regarded as necessary to protect the applicant from further harassment (if applicable); and
show why a direction that the restraining order apply against an associated respondent is sought (if applicable), including—
details of the way in which the respondent is encouraging or has encouraged the associated respondent’s behaviour; and
an outline, similar to that required by paragraph (a), of the nature and history of the harassment that the applicant alleges the associated respondent has engaged in.

If an application is made under section 13 of the Act by a representative, an affidavit containing the matters specified in subclauses (2) and (3) may be made by any person who has knowledge of the relevant facts.

prov.heading: Number of copies to be filed

para.text: There must be filed with every main application the number of copies of the application and the accompanying documents that the Registrar directs is required for service.

prov.heading: Request that residential address be kept confidential

para.text: In this rule and in rule 20.36, applicant means—
a person who applies for a restraining order; and
a protected person who is a party to a proceeding under the Act.
An applicant who wishes that his or her residential address be kept confidential from the other party or parties must file a notice in form 95—
stating the applicant’s residential address; and
requesting that the address be kept confidential.

On filing the notice in accordance with subclause (2), the applicant is not required to disclose the applicant’s residential address in a document that is available to another party (despite any other rule).

To the extent that a document discloses any matter that is to be kept confidential in accordance with this rule or rule 20.36, the document may not be searched, inspected, or copied under Part 3 unless the court otherwise directs.
An applicant who changes his or her address from that shown in a notice filed in accordance with subclause (2) may, by notice in form 95, notify that change of address to the Registrar.
Neither this rule nor rule 20.36 affects the obligation to state an address for service in accordance with rule 5.47.

prov.heading: Request that address of applicant’s solicitor be kept confidential

para.text: If an applicant’s solicitor has instructed another solicitor (the agent) to act as the agent of the applicant’s solicitor in the proceeding, the applicant may also request in the notice filed under rule 20.35(2) that the name and address of the applicant’s solicitor be kept confidential.
When subclause (1) applies,—
the name of the applicant’s solicitor is not required to be disclosed in a document that is available to another party if the name of the agent is disclosed in that document; and
any rule requiring disclosure of the name of the applicant’s solicitor in a document that is available to another party may be complied with by disclosing the name of the agent.

prov.heading: Proper registry for filing main application

para.text: The proper registry, for the purposes of rule 20.30, is—
the court nearest to the place where the applicant or one of the applicants resides; or
the court nearest to the place specified by the applicant or one of the applicants as his or her address for service; or
the court nearest to the place where the respondent or an associated respondent resides; or
with the written consent of every respondent and every associated respondent, any other court.
Written consent given under subclause (1)﻿(d) must be filed with the application.
The Registrar may refuse to file a proceeding that, in the Registrar’s opinion, is tendered for filing in the wrong court.
If the Registrar refuses to file a proceeding, the applicant may apply to a Judge for a direction that the applicant is entitled to file the proceeding in that court.
If a proceeding is started in the wrong court, a Judge may, on any terms and conditions that the Judge considers appropriate,—
transfer the proceeding to the court in which it ought to have been started; or
order that the proceeding continue in the court in which it was started.
No objection may be taken at the hearing or at a subsequent proceeding on the ground that the proceeding was filed in the wrong court.
Subclause (4) does not limit subclause (3).
The Registrar must do the following if a main application is filed:
enter the application in the records of the court; and
fix a date and time for the hearing of the application, which must be as soon as practicable; and
inform all parties to the proceeding of the date and time fixed for the hearing; and
ensure that the respondent and any associated respondent is served with copies of—
the application; and
the notice of proceeding; and
the affidavit accompanying the application.

prov.heading: Requirement to file and serve notice of defence or address for service

para.text: A respondent or an associated respondent who intends to defend a main application must, not less than 5 working days before the date set for the hearing, file in court—
a notice of defence in form 96; and
an affidavit setting out sufficient particulars to indicate the grounds on which the defence is based, and sufficient information to inform the court of the facts relied on in support of the defence.
The notice of defence and affidavit required to be filed in court under subclause (1) must be served on the applicant not less than 5 working days before the date set for the hearing.
Subclauses (1) and (2) are subject to any directions given by a Judge in relation to any particular case.
A respondent who does not intend to defend a main application may give an address for service by filing in court a notice of that address and serving a copy on every other party to the proceeding.

prov.heading: Consequences of failure to file and serve notice of defence

para.text: If a respondent or an associated respondent fails to comply with rule 20.40(1) or (2), the court may—
strike out the defence; or
allow the respondent or associated respondent to defend the application, or appear at the hearing, only on such terms as the court considers appropriate.
Subclause (1) does not limit any other power the court may exercise if a party fails to comply with these rules.

prov.heading: Appointment of representative of certain minors

para.text: This rule applies to a minor who—
is under 16 years of age; or
is 16 years of age and elects under section 11(2A) of the Act to make an application for a restraining order by a representative.
For the purposes of section 11 of the Act, a representative of a minor to whom this rule applies must be appointed as a litigation guardian of the minor under rule 4.35.
Rules 4.35, 4.36, and 4.41 to 4.45 apply to the minor, and every reference in those rules to an incapacitated person must be read as if it were also a reference to a minor.

A minor who is aged 17 or over, or who has been married or in a civil union or de facto relationship, who wishes to defend an application against him or her for a restraining order must defend the application on his or her own behalf, without a litigation guardian.

prov.heading: Appointment of representative of person unable or unwilling to take proceeding

para.text: Rules 4.41 to 4.46 apply to a representative appointed under section 13 of the Act and to the person on whose behalf the representative was appointed as if each reference in those rules—
to a litigation guardian were a reference to the representative; and
to an incapacitated person were a reference to the person on whose behalf the representative was appointed.

prov.heading: Effect of minor turning 17, marrying, or entering into civil union

para.text: If a minor in relation to whom a representative has been appointed turns 17 years or marries or enters into a civil union before turning 17, all subsequent steps must be taken in the minor’s name.

If the minor continues to prosecute or defend the proceeding, he or she is liable for all the costs of the proceeding (including solicitor and client costs) in the same manner as if he or she had started it or had become a party to it at a time when he or she was not a minor.

prov.heading: Effect of ceasing to be unable or unwilling to take proceedings

para.text: A party on whose behalf a representative was appointed under section 13 of the Act and who ceases to be a person to whom that section applies must take all subsequent steps in the proceeding in the party’s own name.

A party who continues to take steps in the proceeding after he or she ceases to be a person to whom section 13 of the Act applies is liable for all the costs of the proceeding (including solicitor and client costs) in the same manner as if he or she had started it or had become a party to it when he or she was not a person to whom that section applied.

A main application and the documents required under the Act or under this Part to accompany the application must be served personally on every person who is required to be served with the application and those documents.
Subclause (1) is subject to rule 20.50.
Service of the application must be made—
not less than 15 working days before the day of the hearing of the application, if service is effected in New Zealand; or
not less than 21 working days before the day of the hearing of the application, if service is effected out of New Zealand.
The Registrar must serve or cause to be served, without delay, every main application under the Act unless this Part otherwise provides.
Any other document required to be served for the purpose of any proceeding under the Act—
must be served by the Registrar if a Judge so directs:
in the absence of a direction under paragraph (a), may be served by the Registrar.
The Registrar may authorise service of a document that he or she is required to serve under this rule to be effected by—
a bailiff; or
a constable, if—
no bailiff is available to serve the document; or
the court or the Registrar considers it appropriate in the circumstances; or
a solicitor for a party; or
a solicitor acting as agent for that solicitor; or
a person employed or engaged by a party or by either solicitor.
Personal service of a document may not be effected by a party to the proceeding, but the party may be present when service is effected.

If for any sufficient reason service of a document cannot be effected in the manner specified by this Part, the court or a Registrar may give any direction provided for by rule 6.8 (Substituted service) or make any order provided for by that rule.

prov.heading: Power of Judge to call conference

para.text: For the purpose of ensuring that every application under the Act may be determined in a just, expeditious, and economical manner, a Judge may at any time, either on application by either party or their solicitors or counsel or without an application by any of them, on any terms the Judge thinks fit, direct the holding of a conference of—
the parties; or
the solicitors or counsel representing the parties.
The Judge must preside over the conference and may adjourn the conference from time to time and from place to place.
The solicitor or counsel representing any party may attend either in the place of the party or with the party, if the conference is held under subclause (1)﻿(a).
Any party who is not represented by a solicitor or counsel may attend the conference, if the conference is held under subclause (1)﻿(b).
At any conference held under rule 20.51, the Judge presiding may make any orders and give any directions as appear best adapted—
to ensure that the object of the Act (as set out in section 6) is attained; and
to secure the just, expeditious, and economical disposal of the application under the Act.
Subclause (1) includes (without limitation) the power to—
settle the issues to be determined:
direct by whom and within what time any affidavit or other document must be filed:

require any party to make admissions in respect of questions of fact, and, if that party refuses or fails to make an admission in respect of any question of fact, require that party (subject to the direction of the Judge hearing the application) to bear the costs of proving that question at the hearing:
shorten, extend, or fix a time for the filing of any document or the doing of any other thing:
require further or better particulars of any facts or other circumstances connected with the application:
fix a time and place for the hearing of the proceeding:
give any consequential directions that may be necessary.
The court may do the following if a party fails to comply with an order or a direction given or made under this rule:
if the party failing to comply with the order or direction is the applicant, order the proceeding to be dismissed or stayed until the order is complied with:

if the party failing to comply with the order or direction is not the applicant, order that the party be allowed to defend or to appear at the hearing only on any terms the court considers appropriate:
take the failure into account in exercising the court's power to make an order as to costs.
Subclause (3) does not limit any other power the court may exercise where a party fails to comply with an order or direction.
The Registrar may, on the written request of the applicant at any time before the service of an application, amend the application filed in the court.

The Registrar may, on the written request of the respondent, or any associated respondent, at any time before service of a notice of defence or a notice of opposition, amend the notice filed in court.

The court or a Registrar may order that a proceeding filed in a registry of the court be transferred to another registry of the court if the court or, as the case requires, the Registrar is satisfied that the proceeding can be more conveniently or fairly dealt with in that other registry.

The court or a Registrar may order that the hearing of an application filed in a registry of that court be transferred to another registry of the court if the court or, as the case requires, the Registrar is satisfied that the application can be more conveniently or fairly heard in that other court.
The court or a Registrar may order a transfer under rule 20.54 or 20.55—
on the court's or, as the case requires, the Registrar's own initiative; or
on the application of a party on not less than 3 working days' notice.

The applicant may ask the court to review a decision of the Registrar to decline an application to transfer a proceeding or hearing, and in that case the court may make any decision on the application that it thinks fit.
If an order is made for transfer of a proceeding or hearing,—
the order must be endorsed on the application; and
the Registrar must cause notice of the transfer to be given to all parties.
If an order is made under rule 20.54 for the transfer of a proceeding,—
the Registrar of the registry of the court in which the order is made must send to the Registrar of the other registry all the documents in his or her custody relating to the proceeding; and
the Registrar of the registry of the court to which the proceeding is transferred must enter the proceeding in the records of that registry.
On transfer, the proceeding continues as if it had been originally filed in the court to which it has been transferred.
This rule applies with any necessary modifications to the transfer of a proceeding to the High Court under section 43 of the District Courts Act 1947.
If an order is made under rule 20.55 for the transfer of a hearing,—
the Registrar of the registry of the court in which the application is pending must—
send to the Registrar of the other registry all the documents in his or her custody relating to the proceeding; and
note the records of the court accordingly; and
the Registrar of the registry in which the proceeding is to be heard must make an appropriate entry in the records of the court.
For the purposes of the hearing, the application must be dealt with as if it had been filed in the registry of hearing.
When the hearing is concluded,—

the Registrar of the registry of hearing must return all the documents relating to the proceeding, including every order that has been made in that proceeding, to the Registrar of the registry from which the documents were sent; and
the Registrar to whom the documents are returned must record every order made in the proceeding in the records of the court.
A restraining order must be in form 97.

subpart.crosshead: Availability of records for criminal proceedings

prov.heading: Transfer of information to criminal court

para.text: In this rule, harassment offence means an offence against—
section 8 of the Act; or
any other enactment in any case if the offence—

is committed by a person against whom a restraining order is in force, or in respect of whom a proceeding on an application for a restraining order is pending, at the time the offence is committed; and
is committed against a person for whose protection the restraining order was made or has been applied for, as the case may be; and
consists of or includes a specified act within the meaning of section 4 of the Act.
This rule applies if, in the course of a criminal proceeding in respect of a harassment offence, there is reason to believe that—
the defendant in that criminal proceeding is or has been a respondent or an associated respondent to a proceeding (the civil proceeding) under the Act for a restraining order; and

information relating to the civil proceeding may be relevant to the criminal proceeding, including (without limitation) for the purposes of assisting with the preparation of a probation officer's report under section 26 of the Sentencing Act 2002.

When this rule applies, the court dealing with the criminal proceeding, or a Registrar of that court, may request the Registrar of the registry of the court in which the civil proceeding was brought to supply either or both of the following:
information about the current status of the civil proceeding:
a copy of any order made in the civil proceeding.

A Registrar to whom a request is made under subclause (3) must, without delay, provide to the requesting court or Registrar as much of the information requested as the requested Registrar has available to him or her.
Subpart 2 of Part 7 applies with the necessary modifications to interlocutory applications made in proceedings under the Act.

prov.heading: Applications for extending time used as delaying tactic

para.text: No order extending time may be made under rule 1.23 if it appears to the court or the Registrar, as the case may be, that the application for the order is made with the principal object of delaying the proceeding to the detriment of the other party.

subpart.heading: Proceedings under subpart 6 of Part 8 of Local Government Act 2002

para.text: This subpart applies to proceedings under subpart 6 of Part 8 of the Local Government Act 2002.
In this subpart, unless the context otherwise requires, Act means the Local Government Act 2002.

prov.heading: Application of rules in other Parts

para.text: The following rules do not apply to proceedings under the Act:
rule 5.1 (which is about how to determine the proper registry):
rule 5.24 (which is about a notice requiring further particulars or a more explicit pleading:
rule 7.45 (which is about an application for an injunction):
rule 8.34 to 8.46 (which is about interrogatories):
rules 10.1 to 10.8 (which are about the mode of trial):
Part 12 (which is about summary judgment).

Unless excluded by subclause (1), the provisions of a rule in another Part apply to proceedings under subpart 6 of Part 8 of the Act so far as they are applicable and with the necessary modifications.
For the purpose of applying a rule in accordance with subclause (2), pleading includes an application for a removal order and a notice of objection.
A proceeding is started by filing an application for a removal order under section 215 of the Act in the court that is nearest to the property to which the application relates.
The proper heading of an application is form 2.
An application for a removal order must be in form 98.
The application must state whether the applicant seeks—
removal or alteration of all or part of the fence, vegetation, or structure:
a consequential order, including an order that entry be made onto any portion of land adjoining the property to which the application relates:
directions as to service under clause 2 of Schedule 14 of the Act.
An application for the alteration of all or part of the fence, structure, or vegetation—
must state the nature of that alteration; and
may have a drawing or plan of the alteration attached to it.
An affidavit made by or on behalf of the applicant, setting out the matters on which the application is based, must be filed with every application for a removal order.
The affidavit must contain sufficient information to inform the court of—
the grounds on which the application is based; and
the facts relied on in support of the application; and
the reasons for seeking the removal of all or part of a fence, a structure, or vegetation (if applicable); and
the reasons for seeking the alteration of all or part of a fence, a structure, or vegetation (if applicable); and
the reasons why entry onto a portion of land adjoining the property is necessary to enforce a removal or alteration (if applicable).

prov.heading: Procedure on applications for removal order

para.text: The Registrar must fix a date and time for a hearing if an appearance is necessary or required for an application for a removal order, and must inform the applicant accordingly.
The Registrar must immediately inform the applicant of the terms of any order made on an application for which no appearance is necessary or required.
A removal order must be in form 99.

prov.heading: Service of removal order on respondent

para.text: After a removal order is made, the respondent must, without delay, be served with a copy of—
the removal order; and
the application for the order; and
each affidavit filed in support of the application.

Despite subclause (1), a Judge or Registrar may direct that the removal order is to be served on the respondent without 1 or more of the copies required by subclause (1)﻿(b) and (c), but in that case must direct that the respondent be given the opportunity to collect the documents not served on the respondent from a specified place.
Subclause (1) is subject to any direction given by the court under clause 2 of Schedule 14 of the Act.

prov.heading: Service of removal order on other parties

para.text: After a removal order is made, all persons (other than the respondent) entitled to object under section 217(1) of the Act must, without delay, be served with a copy of—
the removal order; and
a notice in form 100.

A copy of the application for the order and the affidavit or affidavits filed in support of the application need not be served on a person to whom subclause (1) applies, but the Registrar must, on request, make copies of those documents available to that person.
Subclause (1) is subject to any direction given by the court under clause 2 of Schedule 14 of the Act.

prov.heading: Mode of service of removal order

para.text: A removal order must be served personally unless subclause (2) or (3) applies.
A removal order may be served on a respondent who is the occupier of the property to which the order relates by leaving a copy of the order in a prominent position at the property.

If for any sufficient reason a removal order cannot be served in the manner specified by this rule, the court or a Registrar may give any direction provided for by rule 6.8 (Substituted service) or make any order provided for by that rule.
This rule is subject to any direction given by the court under clause 2 of Schedule 14 of the Act as to the manner in which service is to be effected on a specified party.
This rule does not apply to service of an order that confirms, varies, or discharges the removal order following the making of an objection.
A notice of objection must be in form 101.
A notice of objection must state whether the objector seeks a discharge of the removal order or whether a specified variation of the order would meet the objector’s concerns.
An affidavit must accompany every notice of objection and must contain sufficient information to inform the court of—
the facts relied on in support of the objection; and
the facts relied on in support of the proposed variation of the order (if applicable).
If a party who wishes to object to a removal order fails to file a notice of objection in form 101 accompanied by an affidavit described in subclause (3), the court may—
strike out the objection; or
if an oral hearing is to be held to decide the objection, allow the party wishing to object to appear at the hearing only on any terms that the court considers appropriate.
Subclause (4) does not limit any other power the court may exercise where a party fails to comply with these rules.

prov.heading: Manner in which notice of objection to be dealt with

para.text: The Registrar must, if an oral hearing is to be held under clause 7 of Schedule 14 of the Act, notify every person who has been served with a copy of the removal order that he or she is entitled to—
appear at the hearing, either in person or by his or her solicitor or counsel; or
make submissions in writing in relation to the objection.

The Registrar must, if the court has determined to decide an objection made by a person described in clause 3(a)﻿(iii) to (v) of Schedule 14 of the Act without an oral hearing, notify the applicant and every other person entitled to object under section 217(1) of the Act that he or she may make written submissions in relation to the objection.

A written submission made in response to a notice given under subclause (1)﻿(b) or (2) must be lodged with the court within 5 working days after the date on which the Registrar notifies the objector under either of those provisions, or within any longer period that the court may specify in the notice.

The Registrar must ensure that a copy of the objection accompanies a notice given under subclause (1) or (2) if a copy of the objection has not previously been served on the person to whom the notice is given.
A Registrar may exercise the powers of the court under—
clause 7(3) of Schedule 14 of the Act (to determine whether objections by persons other than the respondent or the owner are to be decided with or without an oral hearing); and
clause 7(4) of Schedule 14 of the Act (to decide whether hearings are to be heard together).
Subpart 2 of Part 7 applies with the necessary modifications to interlocutory applications made in proceedings under subpart 6 of Part 8 of the Act.

prov.heading: Applications for extending time used as delaying tactic

para.text: No order extending time may be made under rule 1.23 if it appears to the court or the Registrar, as the case may be, that there is no genuine reason or excuse for the application.

subpart.crosshead: Entry of land to enforce removal orders

prov.heading: Notice where land entered to enforce removal order

para.text: The notice of entry required to be given under section 221(1)﻿(d) of the Act by an applicant to the relevant owner and occupier,—
following entry of the property to which the order relates, must be in form 102:
following entry of a property adjoining the property to which the order relates, must be in form 103.
A notice referred to in subclause (1) may be served—
on the occupier by leaving the notice in a prominent position on the property that was entered:
by posting the notice to the owner’s address, if the owner is not the occupier.

subpart.heading: Proceedings under Construction Contracts Act 2002

para.text: This subpart applies to—
an application for review; and
an application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced.
In this subpart, unless the context otherwise requires,—
Act means the Construction Contracts Act 2002
application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced—
means an application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced by entry as a judgment in accordance with subpart 2 of Part 4 of the Act; and

if the adjudicator has recorded in the adjudicator’s determination his or her approval for the issue of a charging order in respect of a construction site, includes an application, under section 76(2)﻿(a) of the Act, for the issue of that charging order
application for review means an application made by an owner who is not a respondent under section 52 of the Act for a review of—
an adjudicator’s determination that the owner is jointly and severally liable with the respondent to make a payment to the claimant; and
an adjudicator’s approval for the issue of a charging order in respect of the construction site
party to the relevant adjudication proceedings—
means the claimant or the respondent in those proceedings; and
if the context requires, includes the owner of the construction site who was not a respondent in, but was a party to, those proceedings
Regulations means the Construction Contracts Regulations 2003
relevant adjudication proceedings means the adjudication proceedings that relate to—
an application for review; or
an application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced.

prov.heading: Application of other rules and practice of court

para.text: The other Parts of these rules, the District Courts Act 1947, and the general practice of the court (including the procedure and practice in chambers) apply if this Part applies except in so far as they are modified by, or inconsistent with, the Act or this Part.

subpart.crosshead: Review of adjudicator’s determination in respect of owner who is not respondent

para.text: An application for review must be made by filing a notice in form 4 of Schedule 1 of the Regulations within the time set out in section 53(2) of the Act.

prov.heading: Where to file application for review

para.text: An application for review must be filed in the registry of the court nearest to the place at which the relevant adjudication proceedings were held.

prov.heading: Procedure after filing of application for review

para.text: After an application for review is filed,—
the Registrar must—
enter the application in the records of the court; and
refer the application to a Judge without delay; and
endorse on the copy of the application to be served by the applicant under paragraph (b) the date and time that has been fixed for the hearing; and
the applicant must serve a copy of the application that is endorsed with the date and time fixed for the hearing, and of any accompanying documents, on—
the respondent; and
any other party to the relevant adjudication proceedings.
It is not necessary to serve a copy of the application for review on the adjudicator whose determination is the subject of the application, unless the court otherwise directs.

prov.heading: Notice of opposition to application for review

para.text: If a party to the relevant adjudication proceedings intends to oppose the application for review, that party must, within 15 working days after being served with the application,—
file in the court a notice of opposition; and
serve a copy of the notice and of any accompanying documents on—
the applicant; and
any other party to the relevant adjudication proceedings.
The notice must state—
the party’s intention to oppose the application; and
the grounds of opposition.
It is not necessary to serve a copy of the notice on the adjudicator whose determination is the subject of the application, unless the court otherwise directs.

prov.heading: Adjudicator to forward documents relating to adjudication proceedings on request

para.text: An adjudicator whose determination is the subject of an application for review must, on the request of the Registrar, forward to the court all documents in his or her custody relating to the determination within 5 working days after receiving the request.

prov.heading: Application for adjudicator’s determination to be enforced

para.text: An application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced must—
be in form 104; and
be accompanied by a copy of the adjudicator’s determination that is sought to be enforced.
The application must be filed in the registry of the court nearest to the place at which the relevant adjudication proceedings were held.

Either before or immediately after the filing of an application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced, the plaintiff must serve a copy of the application and of any accompanying documents on—
the defendant; and
any other party to the relevant adjudication proceedings.

prov.heading: Opposition to application for adjudicator’s determination to be enforced

para.text: A defendant who wishes to oppose the application for an adjudicator’s determination to be enforced must, within 15 working days after the date on which a copy of the application is served on the defendant,—
file an application in the court seeking an order that enforcement of the adjudicator’s determination be refused; and
serve a copy of the application and of any accompanying documents on—
the plaintiff; and
any other party to the relevant adjudication proceedings.
The application must be in form 105.
This subpart applies to proceedings in the District Court in its admiralty jurisdiction.
In this Part, unless the context otherwise requires,—
Act means the Admiralty Act 1973
Registrar means a Registrar of the District Court, and includes a Deputy Registrar.

prov.heading: Application of other rules and practice of court

para.text: The other Parts of these rules, the District Courts Act 1947, and the general practice of the court (including the procedure and practice in chambers) apply if this Part applies except in so far as they are modified by, or inconsistent with, the Act or this Part.

prov.heading: Preliminary acts to be filed in collision cases

para.text: In an action arising out of a collision between ships, unless the court otherwise orders on the application of any intended party to the proceedings,—
the plaintiff must file a preliminary act when filing the statement of claim and the notice of proceeding:
the defendant must file a preliminary act when filing the statement of defence.
A preliminary act is a document containing a statement of the following particulars:
the names of the ships that came into collision and their ports of registry:
