para.text: I, the defendant, against whom a writ of arrest has been issued under section 109 of the District Courts Act 1947, consent that the plaintiff's claim may be summarily heard and finally adjudicated immediately/at [time, date]*.
(defendant)
Before me: [name, signature]
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar/solicitor/Justice of the Peace*)

form.heading: Order against executor or administrator in respect of assets received since judgment

para.text: In the District Court at [place]
No: [number of proceeding]
Between [full name] (plaintiff)
And [full name], the executor/administrator* of [full name] (deceased), (defendant)

heading.emphasis: To the defendant

para.text: At the hearing of this proceeding on [date], it was adjudged that the plaintiff should recover against the defendant the sum of $[amount] for [specify] and $[amount] for costs, and it was ordered that the sums be levied on the assets of the deceased's estate that should subsequently come into the hands of the defendant as executor/administrator* to be administered.
On the application of the plaintiff, it appears to the court that, since the judgment, assets of the deceased's estate have come into the hands of this defendant as executor/administrator*.
This court orders that the sums be levied on the assets of the deceased's estate that have come into the hands of the defendant as executor/administrator* since the date of the judgment.
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

In the District Court at [place]
Under the Harassment Act 1997
[Full name, *address, occupation]

[Full name, *address, occupation]
(respondent)

Rule 20.35 of the District Courts Rules 2014 permits the residential address of an applicant for a restraining order or of a protected person to be omitted from this heading if he or she wants the address to be kept confidential from the other parties.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 form 91: amended, on 1 January 2015, by rule 9(4) of the District Courts Amendment Rules 2014 (LI 2014/347).

form.heading: Application for restraining order

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 91.
For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: I, [full name], apply for a restraining order against [full name], the respondent.
I, [full name], the appointed representative of [full name], the applicant, apply on behalf of the applicant for a restraining order against [full name], the respondent.

text.emphasis: Include this paragraph if the order is sought for a period of more or less than 1 year.

para.text: The proposed duration of the order sought is a period of [specify period].
I seek a direction that the restraining order apply against [full name(s)], the associated respondent/associated respondents*.

text.emphasis: Include this paragraph if you wish to request special conditions.

para.text: I request that the following special conditions be part of the restraining order: [set out in sufficient detail the nature of the special conditions sought].
I rely on the content of my/[name of deponent if deponent is not the applicant],* affidavit dated [date] filed in support of this application.
Signature:
(applicant)

text.emphasis: The Registrar is to complete the following appointment for hearing.

para.text: I appoint [date, time] at the District Court at [place] for the hearing of this application.
Signature:
(Registrar)

An affidavit must be filed with this application. The affidavit must contain sufficient particulars to show the grounds on which you claim to be entitled to the order and to inform the court of the facts relied on. In particular, it must state the matters required to be stated by rule 20.33 of the District Courts Rules 2014.
Where the application is made by a representative, the accompanying affidavit or affidavits can be made by anyone with knowledge of the relevant facts.
A notice of proceeding in form 23 must also be filed with this application.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registry of the District Court is open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

form.heading: Application for variation or discharge of restraining order

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 91.
Select the statement that applies.

para.text: I, [full name], apply for an order that the restraining order made in the District Court at [place, date, time] be varied by [specify nature of variation sought by referring to section 22(1) of the Act] on the following grounds: [specify grounds].
I, [full name], apply for an order discharging the restraining order made in the District Court at [place, date, time] on the following grounds: [specify grounds].
I rely on the content of the affidavit dated [date] (of [name of deponent if deponent is not the applicant])* filed in support of this application.

row.entry: *Omit this phrase if it does not apply.

para.text: Signature:
(applicant)

text.emphasis: The Registrar is to complete the following appointment for hearing.

para.text: I appoint [date, time] at the District Court at [place] for the hearing of this application.
Signature:
(Registrar)
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registry of the District Court is open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

form.heading: Notice of proceeding

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To [full name] (the respondent)

para.text: and
*To [full name] (the associated respondent)

text.emphasis: Select the statement that applies.
Statement A
Notification of application for restraining order

para.text: [Full name] has filed an application for a restraining order against you/the respondent*.

text.emphasis: Statement B
Notification of application for variation of restraining order

para.text: [Full name] has filed an application for variation of the restraining order made in the District Court at [place, date] between [full name], the protected person, and [full name], the respondent, *and [full name], the associated respondent.

row.entry: *Omit this phrase if it does not apply.

text.emphasis: Statement C
Notification of application for discharge of restraining order

para.text: [Full name] has filed an application for discharge of the restraining order made in the District Court at [place, date] on between [full name], the protected person, and [full name], the respondent, *and [full name], the associated respondent.

row.entry: *Omit this phrase if it does not apply.

text.emphasis: Statement D
Notification of application for variation or discharge of restraining order by associated respondent

para.text: [Full name], the associated respondent, has filed an application for variation/discharge* of the restraining order made in the District Court at [place, date] between [full name], the protected person, and [full name], the respondent, and [full name], the associated respondent, in so far as the order affects him/her*.
A copy of the application is attached. The nature of the order or orders sought is specified in the application, which also states the date of the hearing.
The applicant's address for service is [address].
Signature:
(applicant/solicitor for applicant*)

If you wish to defend the application, you may file a notice of defence in this office of the court at least 5 working days before the date of the hearing. An affidavit must be filed with the notice of defence. A copy of the notice of defence must be served on the other party. That copy may be delivered to the address for service given by that person.
If you do nothing, the hearing may proceed and the court can make an order in your absence.
If you do not wish to defend the application but you do wish to know what is happening, you should—
file in this registry of the court a notice giving the address of a place in New Zealand at which documents can be left for you; and
serve a copy of the notice on the other party to the proceeding. That copy may be delivered to the address for service given by that person.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registry of the District Court is open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

form.heading: Notice of residential address and request for confidentiality

My solicitor’s name and address are: [name, address].

(applicant)

To the applicant/[applicant and either the respondent or the associate respondent, or both, as the case may be]*

(respondent)/(associated respondent)*
This notice is filed by [full name] whose address for service is [address].

history.history-note: Schedule 2 form 96: amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 10(1) of the District Courts Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/103).

form.heading: Restraining order

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 91.

para.text: On application, the court makes a restraining order against [full name], the respondent.

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: The court also directs that the order applies against the following person/persons*: [full name of each person in respect of whom the court makes a direction under section 18(1) of the Harassment Act 1997].
This order expires on [date] unless earlier extended.

text.emphasis: This order protects [name], the protected person. The conditions of the order are as follows:

head5.heading: Standard conditions prohibiting harassment and contact

para.text: It is a condition of this order that the respondent, and any associated respondent, must not—
do, or threaten to do, any specified act (set out below) to the protected person; or
encourage any person to do any specified act to the protected person, where the act, if done by the respondent or any associated respondent, would be prohibited by this order.
A specified act is any 1 of the following acts:

watching, loitering near, or preventing or hindering access to or from, the protected person's place of residence, business, employment, or any other place that the protected person frequents for any purpose; or
following, stopping, or accosting the protected person; or
entering, or interfering with, property in the possession of the protected person; or
making contact with that person (whether by telephone, correspondence, or in any other way); or
giving offensive material to the protected person, or leaving it where it will be found by, given to, or brought to the attention of that person; or
acting in any other way that—
causes the protected person to fear for his or her safety; and
that would cause a reasonable person in that person's particular circumstances to fear for his or her safety.
A specified act is regarded as being done to the protected person if—
it is done to a person with whom the protected person is in a family relationship; and
the doing of the act is due wholly or partly to the protected person's family relationship with that person.
The court also imposes the following special conditions: [specify].
Unless otherwise stated, these special conditions last until the order expires.
Signature:
(applicant)

This order prohibits you from having contact with the protected person in any of the ways specified above. The order may also contain special conditions relating to contact between you and the protected person. You should read the terms of the order very carefully to find out what contact you may not have with the protected person and persons with whom the protected person has a family relationship.
Unless the order states that this restraining order lasts for a different period, it will remain in force for 1 year, starting the day after the date on which it was made.

head5.heading: Modification or discharge of this order

para.text: You (or any other party, including the respondent or any associated respondent) can apply to the court at any time—
for a variation or discharge of any special conditions of this order, or for the imposition of a new special condition:
for the duration of this order to be varied, if the court is satisfied that an extension is necessary to protect you from further harassment:
for this order to be discharged.

head5.heading: Consequences of a breach of this order

para.text: You commit an offence if, without reasonable excuse, you—
contravene this order; or
fail to comply with any condition of this order.

The maximum penalty for this offence is imprisonment for 6 months or a $5,000 fine. However, in the case of certain repeat offences, the maximum penalty for this offence increases to imprisonment for 2 years.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registries of the District Court are open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

The effect of this order is to prohibit the respondent or associated respondent from having contact with you in any of the ways set out in the order. This order may also contain special conditions relating to contact between you and the respondent or associated respondent.
The order also prevents the respondent or associated respondent from having contact with anyone with whom you have a family relationship if that contact is due partly or wholly to that relationship.
Unless the order states that this restraining order lasts for a different period, it will remain in force for 1 year from the date on which it was made.

head5.heading: Modification or discharge of this order

para.text: You (or any other party, including the respondent or any associated respondent) can apply to the court at any time—
for a variation or discharge of any special conditions of this order, or for the imposition of a new special condition:
for the duration of this order to be varied, if the court is satisfied that an extension is necessary to protect you from further harassment:
for this order to be discharged.
If the respondent or associated respondent makes any of these applications, you will be notified and have an opportunity to dispute the application.

head5.heading: Consequences of a breach of this order

para.text: The respondent or associated respondent commits an offence if, without reasonable excuse, they—
contravene this order; or
fail to comply with any condition of this order.

The maximum penalty for this offence is imprisonment for 6 months or a $5,000 fine. However, in the case of certain repeat offences, the maximum penalty for this offence increases to imprisonment for 2 years.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court office immediately.
The registries of the District Court are open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 form 97: amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 10(2) of the District Courts Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/103).

form.heading: Application for removal order

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

para.text: I, [full name, occupation], apply for a removal order against [full name, address, occupation (if known)], the respondent.
The order is sought in respect of the property at [specify the street address or other locality description in sufficient detail to enable it to be clearly identified].

The removal/alteration* is sought of the fence/structure/vegetation† located on [specify the location of the particular fence, structure, or vegetation on the property in sufficient detail to enable it to be clearly identified].

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: The following alterations are sought to the fence/structure/vegetation*: [specify the nature of the alterations sought. Where removal is sought of one part of the fence and alteration of another, specify the proposal in sufficient detail to inform the court. A drawing or diagram may be attached to explain the orders sought].

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: The following further orders are sought: [specify—
any order sought that any thing attached to the fence, structure, or vegetation is to be removed as a consequence of the removal or alteration:
any other consequential order sought].

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: A further order is sought authorising entry onto [identify any adjoining land that would need to be entered to enforce the removal order sought

head5.heading: Costs and expenses of complying with order sought

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: A direction is sought that the respondent not be required to pay the costs and expenses of complying with the removal order sought.
Note: Section 220 of the Local Government Act 2002 provides that, unless a removal order directs otherwise, the respondent must pay all the costs and expenses of complying with the order.
The respondent is the owner/occupier*.
In addition to the respondent, the following persons will be served with a copy of the order:

text.emphasis: Select the paragraph(s) that apply.

para.text: the owner of the property, whose name and address is: [complete where respondent is not owner].
the mortgagees of the property, whose names and addresses are: [complete where the property is subject to a mortgage].
the owners of any property adjoining the property to which the application relates, whose names and addresses are: [names, addresses].

text.emphasis: For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: A direction as to service is sought in respect of the following person/persons* likely to be affected by the outcome of the proceeding: [if known, give names and addresses of persons concerned and indicate the way in which they are likely to be affected].
Apart from the persons listed in paragraph [number], there do not appear to be any persons who are likely to be affected by the outcome of the proceeding.

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: Directions are sought on the manner in which the following persons are to be served: [specify person concerned and the proposed nature of the direction sought].
I rely on the content of the affidavit/affidavits* dated [date(s)] filed in support of this application.
I wish/do not wish* to be heard in support of this application.
Signature:
(applicant/person authorised to sign on behalf of applicant*)

form.heading: Removal order

text.emphasis: To [full name, address] (respondent)

para.text: The court makes this removal order because it is satisfied that—
The property at [clearly identify street address or other locality] is occupied, or regularly used, by persons who have been convicted of/have committed/are committing/are likely to commit* offences.

text.emphasis: For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: The fence/structure/vegetation* described below has facilitated or contributed to, is facilitating or contributing to, or is intended to facilitate or contribute to [select one of the following paragraphs:

the concealment on the property of any unauthorised weapon or any controlled drug or any tainted property or any property that is stolen or obtained by a crime involving dishonesty [specify reasons why this ground applies].
the avoidance of detection or arrest of any person or persons believed or reasonably suspected to have committed any offence or offences [specify reasons why this ground applies].
the commission of any offence or offences by any person or persons on or from the property [specify reasons why this ground applies].]
The fence/structure/vegetation* described below is intended to injure any person [specify reasons why this ground applies].
The fence/structure/vegetation* described below is such that the court is satisfied that it may reasonably be regarded as intimidating.
The court makes the following order/orders* against the respondent:

The respondent must remove/alter* the fence/structure/vegetation† as follows: [identify, either in the order itself or by reference to documents attached to the order, the location of any fence, structure, or vegetation to be removed or altered and specify the action required to be taken].

The respondent must also remove the following attachments from the fence/structure/vegetation*: [list attachments (such as video cameras, sensors, barbed wire) to be removed as a consequence of the removal or alteration referred to above].

The court also makes the following consequential orders and gives the following directions: [set out any other consequential orders made, any directions as to service, and any direction relating to the costs of compliance].

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: If this removal order needs to be enforced, entry may be made onto [identify portion of land adjoining property to which the order relates] in accordance with section 221 of the Local Government Act 2002.

head5.heading: Period within which action must be taken

para.text: The respondent must comply with this order within [specify]. [The period must be a reasonable period, having regard to the circumstances giving rise to the removal order.]
Signature:
(Registrar)

You may object to the making of this order. Every other person on whom this order is served may also object. A notice of objection must be in writing and contain certain information. (You can see an example of the form of the notice of objection at any registry of the District Court.) It must be lodged with the court and served on the applicant within 15 working days from the date on which the removal order is served on you (or within such further time as the court may allow).
If a notice of objection is lodged, the removal order cannot be enforced until the court has made its decision on the objection.
The court may confirm, vary, or discharge the order. If the order is confirmed or varied, the court will specify the date by which you must comply with the order.

head5.heading: Consequences if notice of objection not filed and order not complied with

para.text: If no objection is made to the order and you do not comply with this order within the period specified in the order for compliance, the applicant may enter the property without further notice and may use reasonable force to remove or alter the fence, structure, or vegetation in accordance with the terms of the order.

Any materials salvaged in removing or altering the fence, structure, or vegetation will be sold to recover the applicant's costs. If this does not cover all the costs, the applicant can recover the outstanding costs from you.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registry of the District Court is open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

form.heading: Notice of making of removal order

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To [names of persons other than respondent who are entitled to be served]

text.emphasis: The court has made a removal order in respect of the property at [address or other locality description]. A copy of the order is attached for your information.

para.text: You have been served with a copy of this order because you are one of the following:
the owner of the property:
the owner of an adjoining property:
the mortgagee of the property:
a person who is likely to be affected by the outcome of the proceeding.

You may object to the order. A notice of objection must be in writing and contain certain information. (You can see an example of the form of the notice of objection at any registry of the District Court.) The objection must be lodged with the court and served on the applicant within 15 working days from the date on which the removal order is served on you (or such further time as the court may allow).
If an objection is lodged, the removal order cannot be enforced until the court has made its decision.
If you object, you can tell the court whether you (or your lawyer) wish to have an oral hearing.

text.emphasis: Omit the following paragraph if you are the owner.

para.text: The court can decide to deal with your objection without an oral hearing.

If there is to be an oral hearing at which you (or your lawyer) can appear, you will be notified. You can make a written submission to the court instead of appearing at the hearing. A written submission must be lodged with the court within 5 working days after you are notified of the hearing or within any longer period specified in the notice.

If there will not be an oral hearing to decide the objection, the Registrar will notify you that you can make a written submission to the court. A written submission must be lodged with the court within 5 working days after you are notified or within any longer period specified in the notice.

Certain other people may also be able to object to the order. If so, all the objections may be dealt with together. If those other people do not wish to object, they may nevertheless be given an opportunity to comment on your objection before the court makes its decision.
After considering any objection to a removal order, the court may confirm the order, vary the order, or discharge the order.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registry of the District Court is open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.
Signature:
(Registrar)

form.heading: Notice of objection to removal order

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To the Registrar

para.text: and
To the applicant/applicant and respondent [if the objector is not the respondent]*
I, [full name], [specify one of the following:

text.emphasis: the respondent
the owner of the property to which the removal order relates
a mortgagee of the property to which the removal order relates
the owner of any property adjoining the property to which the removal order relates

para.text: a person who has been served with the removal order in accordance with a direction given by the court],

object to the removal order made on [date] in favour of [full name], the applicant, against me/[full name of respondent if objection made by person other than respondent]*, the respondent, in respect of [clearly identify street address or other locality].
The reasons for my objection are: [specify].
I rely on the content of the affidavit/affidavits* dated [date] filed in support of this objection.
I request that—

text.emphasis: Omit whichever of the following paragraphs does not apply.

para.text: the order be discharged:
the terms of the order be varied as follows: [specify variation sought. The supporting affidavit must set out the facts relied on in support of the proposed variation].
I wish to appear/do not wish to appear* at a hearing before the court.
Signature:
(objector)

heading.emphasis: Date of hearing

text.emphasis: The Registrar is to complete the following appointment for hearing if an appearance is required.

para.text: I appoint [date, time] at the District Court at [place] for the hearing of this objection.
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)
This notice must be lodged with the court within 15 working days of the date on which the removal order was served on you (or such further time as the court may allow).

This notice must be accompanied by an affidavit that contains sufficient information to inform the court of the facts relied on in support of the objection and, where a variation of the order is sought, the facts relied on in support of the proposed variation.

You must serve a copy of this notice on the person who applied for the removal order and, if you are not the respondent, on the respondent. Service may be effected at the respondent's address for service.

head6.heading: Omit the following paragraph if it does not apply.

text.emphasis: Hearing of objection made by respondent or owner of property

para.text: If you lodge a notice of objection, you are entitled to appear before the court either in person or by your lawyer, but you must notify the court if you wish to do so.

head6.heading: Omit the following paragraph if it does not apply

text.emphasis: Hearing of objection made by persons other than respondent or owner of property

para.text: If you lodge a notice of objection, you may advise the court that you wish to be heard orally either in person or by your lawyer. The court will then decide whether or not to hold an oral hearing and will notify you accordingly.

Whether or not there is an oral hearing on your objection, you will be notified of the outcome. After considering all objections to a removal order, the court may confirm the order, vary the order, or discharge the order.
If you need help, consult a lawyer or contact a District Court registry immediately.
The registry of the District Court is open from 9 am to 5 pm on Mondays to Fridays inclusive.

form.heading: Notice of entry to owner or occupier of property to which removal order relates

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To [full name], the occupier/owner* of the property at [address or other locality description]

para.text: This document notifies you that the property at [address or other locality description] that you occupy/own* was entered on [date] to remove/alter* the fence/structure/vegetation† that [full name of respondent] has failed to remove or alter in accordance with the removal order made against [name of respondent], the respondent, by the District Court at [place, date, time], a copy of which is attached.
Signature:
(applicant)

Any materials salvaged in removing or altering the fence/structure/vegetation* will be sold to recover the applicant's associated costs. If this does not cover all the costs, the applicant can recover the outstanding amount from the respondent and may register a charge against the property under the Statutory Land Charges Registration Act 1928.

form.heading: Notice of entry to owner or occupier of property adjoining property to which removal order relates

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To [full name], the occupier/owner* of the property at [address or other locality description].

text.emphasis: This document notifies you that—

para.text: The property at [address or other locality description] that you occupy/own* was entered on [date] for the purpose of enforcing a removal order made in respect of the property at [address or other locality description] adjoining your property.
A copy of the removal order made against [name of respondent], the respondent, by the District Court at [place, date, time] is attached.
The removal order authorises entry on your property for the purpose of enforcing the order.
It was necessary to enter your property because the respondent failed to remove/alter* the fence/structure/vegetation† in accordance with the removal order.
Signature:
(applicant)

form.heading: Application for adjudicator's determination to be enforced by entry as judgment

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To the defendant and [names of other parties]

text.emphasis: This document notifies you that—

para.text: The plaintiff seeks to enforce the determination made by [name of adjudicator] on [date] by entry as a judgment.

text.emphasis: Omit this paragraph if it does not apply.

para.text: The plaintiff seeks the issue of a charging order in respect of a construction site.
This application is made under subpart 2 of Part 4 of the Construction Contracts Act 2002 and is accompanied by a copy of the adjudicator's determination.
Signature:
(plaintiff)
You should immediately seek legal advice about this application.

head5.heading: How and when can I oppose this application

para.text: If you wish to oppose this application, you must, within 15 working days after this application is served on you, file in the court and serve on the plaintiff and all other parties to the relevant adjudication proceedings an application for an order that this application be refused.
Your application may be made only on the following grounds:
that the amount payable under the adjudicator's determination has been paid to the plaintiff:
that the contract to which the adjudicator's determination relates is not a construction contract to which the Construction Contracts Act 2002 applies:
that a condition imposed by the adjudicator in his or her determination has not been met.

head5.heading: What will happen if I do not file and serve an application for an order that this application be refused

para.text: If you do not file and serve an application within that period, the Registrar, at the request of the plaintiff, will proceed to—
enter the adjudicator's determination as a judgment; and
if applicable, issue a charging order in respect of the construction site.

form.heading: Application to oppose entry of adjudicator's determination as judgment

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To the plaintiff and [names of other parties to be served]

para.text: This document notifies you that—
I, [full name, address, description of defendant], intend to oppose the application for an order that the adjudicator's determination be enforced by entry as a judgment.
I intend to oppose the application on the following ground/grounds*:

text.emphasis: Select relevant paragraphs.

para.text: that the amount payable under the adjudicator's determination has been paid to the plaintiff:
that the contract to which the adjudicator's determination relates is not a construction contract to which the Construction Contracts Act 2002 applies:
that a condition imposed by the adjudicator in his/her* determination has not been met.
Signature:
(defendant)

form.heading: Application to enter award as judgment

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

heading.emphasis: To the Registrar of the District Court at [place]

para.text: and
To [name(s) of party/parties to be served with this notice]
The plaintiff seeks to enforce the award dated [date] made by [arbitral tribunal name(s)] by entry as a judgment.
This application is made in reliance on article 35 of Schedule 1 of the Arbitration Act 1996.
Signature:
(solicitor/counsel* for plaintiff)
You should seek legal advice immediately about this application.

head5.heading: How and when can I oppose this application?

para.text: You can oppose this application by—
filing an application in the court seeking an order that recognition and enforcement be refused in terms of article 36 of Schedule 1 of the Arbitration Act 1996; and
serving a copy of that application on the plaintiff and on all other parties.
You must do this within whichever of the following periods is shorter:
10 working days after the date on which you are served with this application:
any period fixed by the court of less than 10 working days after you have been served with the order fixing that period.

head5.heading: What will happen if I do not file and serve an application seeking an order that recognition and enforcement be refused?

para.text: If you do not file and serve such an application, the Registrar will proceed to enter the award as a judgment.

history.history-note: Schedule 2 form 106: amended, on 1 July 2015, by rule 10(3) of the District Courts Amendment Rules 2015 (LI 2015/103).

form.heading: Summons for assaulting officer of court or rescuing goods

para.text: In the District Court at [place]

heading.emphasis: To [name, address]

para.text: You are summoned to attend at the District Court at [place, date, time] to answer a complaint made against you by [full name], an officer of the court, and to show cause why an order should not be made against you under the District Courts Act 1947 for payment of a sum not exceeding $300 for—

text.emphasis: Statement A

para.text: an assault committed by you on [date] on the officer while the officer was executing his/her* duty.
rescuing or attempting to rescue on [date] certain goods seized under process of this court.
an assault committed by you on [date] on the officer while the officer was executing his/her* duty and for rescuing or attempting to rescue on [date] certain goods seized under process of this court.
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

form.heading: Order imposing a fine for assaulting an officer of the court, or for rescuing goods

para.text: In the District Court at [place]
This court has adjudged that [full name, address] pay the sum of $[amount] and the sum of $[amount] for costs, amounting in total to a sum of $[amount] for—
committing an assault on [date] on [name], an officer of this court, while the officer was executing his/her* duty.
rescuing or attempting to rescue on [date] certain goods seized under process of this court.

committing an assault on [date] on [name], an officer of this court, while the officer was executing his/her* duty and for rescuing or attempting to rescue on [date] certain goods seized under process of this court.
This court therefore orders you, [name], to pay the sum of $[amount] to the Registrar of this court on [date].
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

form.heading: Summons for extortion or misconduct

para.text: To [name, address], bailiff of the District Court at [place]/[name, address, and title of officer] of the District Court at [place]/[name, address], constable at [place]*
You are summoned to attend at the District Court at [place, date, time] to—

text.emphasis: For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: Answer a complaint made against you by [name, address] that you have (while acting under colour of the process of the court) been guilty of extortion/misconduct* in that you [specify particulars of the extortion or misconduct alleged]†.

row.entry: †Alternatively, attach the particulars of the extortion or misconduct alleged.

para.text: Answer a complaint made against you by [name, address] that you have (while acting under colour of the process of the court) not duly paid or accounted for certain money levied by you against [name] at the suit of [name] under the authority of the District Courts Act 1947.
Show cause why an order should not be made against you under section 70 of the District Court Act 2016 for—
the repayment of the money extorted by you (or for the due payment of the money levied by you), and for the payment of any damages and costs as the District Court Judge thinks just; and
the payment of a fine not exceeding $2,000 for each offence so committed by you.
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

history.history-note: Schedule 2 form 109: amended, on 1 September 2017, by rule 15(4)﻿(a) of the District Court Amendment Rules 2017 (LI 2017/187).
Schedule 2 form 109: amended, on 1 September 2017, by rule 15(4)﻿(b) of the District Court Amendment Rules 2017 (LI 2017/187).

form.heading: Summons for neglect to levy enforcement

heading.emphasis: To [name, address], bailiff of the District Court at [place]/[name, address, and title of officer] of the District Court at [place]/[name, address], constable at [place]*

para.text: You are summoned to attend at the District Court at [place, date, time] to—

answer a complaint made against you by [name, address] that you, being employed to levy an enforcement against the goods and chattels of [name], did by act or omission lose the opportunity of levying that enforcement; and

show cause why an order should not be made against you under section 105 of the District Courts Act 1947 for payment of the damages that [name of complainant] appears to have sustained by your act or omission.
Signature:
(Deputy Registrar/Registrar*)

form.heading: Order for repayment of money extorted, or payment of money levied, and for damages, costs, and fine

para.text: In the District Court at [place]
This court adjudges that [name, address], a bailiff/[specify other officer]* of the court,—

text.emphasis: For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: pay the sum of $[amount] extorted by him/her* from [name] under colour of the process of this court; and

pay the sum of $[amount] levied by him/her* against [name, address] at the suit of [name, address] under the authority of the District Courts Act 1947 and not duly paid over or accounted for by him/her*; and

pay the sum of $[amount] for damages sustained by [name, address] by reason of the extortion by the [specify bailiff or other officer ]/by the neglect of the [specify bailiff or other officer] to pay over the money levied by him or her/by reason of the misconduct of the [specify bailiff or other officer]* while acting under colour of the process of the court in that [specify particulars of misconduct proved].

This court also adjudges that the [specify bailiff or other officer] pay a fine of $[amount] for the offence/for each offence* committed by him/her* [specify particulars of each offence], amounting together to the sum of $[amount].
The court orders that the [specify bailiff or other officer] pay the sum of $[amount] to the Registrar of the court on [date].
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

form.heading: Order awarding damages for neglect to levy enforcement

para.text: In the District Court at [place]

This court adjudges that [name, address], a [specify bailiff or other officer] of this court, pay the sum of $[amount] for damages sustained by [name, address] by reason of [name] having by neglect or connivance or omission lost the opportunity of levying an enforcement against the goods of [name] and the sum of $[amount] for costs, amounting together to the sum of $[amount].
The court orders that the [specify bailiff or other officer] pay the sum of $[amount] to the Registrar of this court on [date].
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

form.heading: Order fining witness for non-attendance

text.emphasis: Complete and insert the heading as set out in form 2.

para.text: [Name, address]—

text.emphasis: For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: was duly summoned to attend as a witness in this proceeding at the District Court at [place, date]; and
was duly summoned to attend as a witness in this proceeding at the District Court at [place, date] and to produce [specify documents]; and
at the time of being summoned was paid/tendered* travelling allowances and expenses according to the scale of allowances prescribed by the District Courts Rules 2014.

text.emphasis: For this paragraph select the statement that applies.

para.text: He/she* has refused or neglected without sufficient cause shown to attend at the court/produce [specify documents]/attend at the court and produce [specify documents]*.
He/she* has refused to [specify case(s) that apply: refused to be sworn, give evidence, or produce documents (specify documents)].
This court orders that [name] pay a fine of $[amount] for such refusal or neglect to the Registrar of the court on [date].
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

form.heading: Warrant of committal for contempt of court

para.text: In the District Court at [place]

heading.emphasis: To a bailiff of the District Court at [place], and to each and every constable in New Zealand, and to the manager of the prison at [place]

para.text: On [date], [full name], the offender, wilfully insulted [name], District Court Judge, in court/[specify other place]* and was ordered to stand committed for [number] days to the prison at [place] for the offence.

This court therefore orders you, the bailiff and others, to take [name] and to deliver him/her* to the manager of the prison, together with this warrant, and you, the manager, to receive [name] and to keep him/her* safely in the prison for [number] days from the arrest under this warrant, or until he/she* is sooner discharged by due course of law.
Signature:
(District Court Judge)

form.heading: Order for fine for contempt of court

para.text: In the District Court at [place]
On [date], [full name], the offender wilfully insulted [name], District Court Judge, in court/[specify other place]*.
This court orders that [name] pay a fine of $[amount] for the offence.
This court also orders that [name] pay a fine of $[amount] for the offence to the Registrar of this court immediately on [date].
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

form.heading: Order for enforcement of payment of fine

para.text: In the District Court at [place]
On [date], [full name, address], was ordered to pay a fine of $[amount] for the offence of [specify].
The fine has not been paid.

This court orders that the payment of the fine of $[amount] be enforced in the same manner as if it had been imposed on conviction of [name] under the provisions of the Summary Proceedings Act 1957 or the Criminal Procedure Act 2011.
Signature:
(Registrar/Deputy Registrar*)

head1.label: Part A
head1.heading: Matters for consideration at first case management conference

para.text: A joint memorandum or separate memoranda must be filed and served in accordance with rule 7.2 as to—
whether initial disclosure has been provided; and
whether the pleadings and the principal documents disclosed with them adequately identify the issues; and
whether further discovery is required before a judicial settlement conference or short trial; and
whether additional parties should be joined; and
the categorisation of the proceeding in relation to costs; and
any other matters.
Note: The parties should discuss and endeavour to agree on the matters listed in this Part of the Schedule.

head1.label: Part B
head1.heading: Matters for consideration at second or subsequent case management conference

para.text: A joint memorandum or separate memoranda must be filed and served in accordance with rules 7.4 and 8.10 as to—
Any of the matters to which Part A of the Schedule applies; and
Whether a short trial, simplified trial or a full trial is required; and
Whether the pleadings require amendment so as to identify the issues; and
Whether additional parties should be joined; and
The scope, terms, and timetable for any discovery additional to discovery previously agreed or ordered; and
If any interlocutory applications have been filed or will be filed, whether they can be heard and disposed of at the case management conference; and
Whether the listing and exchange protocol in Part 2 of Schedule 9 of the High Court Rules should apply.
Whether the case is ready for a fixture date to be allocated; and
Whether a further case management conference or an issues conference should be timetabled; and
If the proceeding is ready for trial,—
the close of pleadings date:
the estimated duration of the trial:
the timetable for written briefs:
whether expert evidence required and, if so, what are the proposals for that evidence (including prior exchange and how the witnesses are to be heard):
any special resources or requirements needed for the hearing:
whether there are any reason why the proceeding cannot be set down as a back-up fixture:
the categorisation of the proceeding in relation to costs; and
If the proceeding is being or has been allocated a hearing or trial date—
whether background facts can be agreed to avoid hearing or contested evidence:
the size, contents, and format of the agreed bundle of documents:
the amount of detail in any chronology of facts:
whether it will be helpful to direct the provision of lists of enactments and cases likely to be referred to:
whether any oral evidence direction should be made under rule 9.10.
Any other matters, provided that those matters have been discussed between the parties at least 5 working days before the conference.
Note: The parties should discuss and endeavour to agree on the matters listed in this Part of the Schedule.

para.text: This is a reprint of the District Court Rules 2014 that incorporates all the amendments to those rules as at the date of the last amendment to them.

Reprints are presumed to correctly state, as at the date of the reprint, the law enacted by the principal enactment and by any amendments to that enactment. Section 18 of the Legislation Act 2012 provides that this reprint, published in electronic form, has the status of an official version under section 17 of that Act. A printed version of the reprint produced directly from this official electronic version also has official status.
Editorial and format changes to reprints are made using the powers under sections 24 to 26 of the Legislation Act 2012. See also http://www.pco.parliament.govt.nz/editorial-conventions/.
